componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Stephanie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Exelon Corporation 2016 Q4 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] 
I would now like to turn the call over to Dan Eggers. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stephanie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our fourth quarter 2016 earnings conference.Call. Leading the call today are Chris Crane, Exelon's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jack Thayer, Exelon's Chief Financial O
componenttext:
Thank you, Stephanie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our fourth quarter 2016 earnings conference.
Call. Leading the call today are Chris Crane, Exelon's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jack Thayer, Exelon's Chief Financial Officer. They're joined by other members of Exelon senior management team, who will be available to answer your questions after our prepared remarks. 
We issued our earnings release this morning, along with the presentation, both of which can be found in the Investor Relations section of Exelon's website. The earnings release and other matters, which we discuss during today's call contain forward-looking statements and estimates that are subject to various risks and uncertainties. Actual results could differ from our forward-looking statements based on factors and assumptions discussed in today's material and comments made during the call. Please refer to today's 8-K and Exelon's other SEC filings for a discussion of risk factors and factors that may cause results to differ from management's projections, forecasts and expectations. 
Today's presentation also includes references to adjusted operating earnings and other non-GAAP measures. Please refer to the information contained in the appendix of our presentation and our earnings release for reconciliation between non-GAAP measures to the nearest equivalent GAAP measures. 
We've scheduled 45 minutes for today's call. I'll turn it over to Chris Crane, Exelon's CEO.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan, and good morning to all. Thank you for joining us. 2016 was a monumental year for Exelon, and I'm very proud of what we've accomplished. We made great progress in the ongoing transformation of our company while delivering on our commitments
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan, and good morning to all. Thank you for joining us. 
2016 was a monumental year for Exelon, and I'm very proud of what we've accomplished. We made great progress in the ongoing transformation of our company while delivering on our commitments. We performed well financially. Our 2016 GAAP earnings at $1.22 and our non-GAAP earnings were $2.68, landing near the top of our original guidance range of $2.40 to $2.70. 
At the utilities, we benefited from a hot summer and low storm costs. At ExGen, the nuclear fleet has its best performance year on record and at Constellation, the team executed very, very well. 
In 2016, for the first time, our regulated utility, less the holding company, earnings represented more than half of the total earnings and is consistent with our goal for the utilities to be a growing the majority of our EPS. 
And we've implemented a dividend growth strategy of 2.5% annually through 2018. 
In March, we closed on the acquisition of PHI, adding $8.3 billion to our utility rate base and creating a significant geographic footprint covering the mid-Atlantic region. The integration of PHI is going better than planned helped by our experience with BGE. We are working our way through the first 2 cycles of catch up rate cases at the PHI utilities. 
We're seeing additional opportunities to help improve the business processes and the stakeholder outreach process as we go through those rate cases. 
The other banner highlight for 2016 was the creation of the ZEC programs in both New York and Illinois. For years, we have argued that all clean energy resources be treated the same way for their environmental our tributes. We're able to work with a wide range of stakeholders in both states to enact programs that compensate these plans for their environmental attributes. 
As a result of these programs, we plan to continue to operate 5 plants and protect high-paying jobs, reserves needed tax basis in rural communities and maintain irreplaceable, emission-free baseload power production. 
These programs provide a supplemental cash flow for up to 12 years for some of our most at risk plans. 
The Illinois legislation also provides significant benefit for our customers in energy efficiency, additional renewable generation and to benefit lower income customers. The program also adds to the earnings visibility at ComEd by implementing a decoupling mechanism, supporting energy efficiency investments where we know will be able to earn on a return on those investments in extending the formula rate to 2022. 
In 2016, we also find ways to grow stable revenue streams. We deployed $5.2 billion of CapEx at the utilities, growing the rate basis by $2 billion, acquired ConEd Solutions and will close the FitzPatrick Nuclear Plant Station this spring. 
We have completed 9 transmission and distribution rate cases, providing revenue increases of $397 million. 
None of these accomplishments would be possible without the remarkable 34,000 employees that work hard every day to keep the power and gas flowing. Our workers donated over 172,000 hours to local nonprofits and Exelon donated $46 million, both of which were the most ever for Exelon. 
The commitment to our community is clearly part of who we are and shows our engagement beyond the products we deliver everyday. 
We also recognize the support of our employees is essential to high-performing work cultures and that is why Exelon took industry lead on 2 important initiatives in 2016. We expanded our pay leave policies to what are truly the best-in-class with 16 weeks of maternity leave, 8 weeks for fathers and adopted parents and 2 weeks of family leave. 
We were also the first utility to sign the White House equal pay push. 
Being a good citizen also means supporting our local businesses. In 2016, our spent with female minority-owned businesses reached $1.9 billion. Over 200% since 2011 and it represents almost 20% of our sourceable spending. The team has done a great job making sure we work with our suppliers across all our communities. 
Doing the right thing by our employees and communities is the smart thing for business, and more importantly, it's the right thing to do. We are proud to be leading the industry forward in these fronts. 
Turning to operations. Our utilities had a great year. The legacy Exelon Utilities continue to perform in top quartile on key operating and customer satisfaction metrics. These are the foundations of a constructed regulatory relationship. 
The efforts at PHI before the merger and our intense focus on operations since then has started to show benefits. 
The color blocks are improving even compared to 2015, although we did get some help from favorable weather in 2016. PHI is still improving. We're encouraged by the gain so far, and we have a plan in place to deliver for our customers and stakeholders. 
The color blocks show great performance, but this actually is underselling how will we did in 2016. We actually had a number of best covers this year: ComEd, BGE; PECO had their best satisfaction ever. ComEd and PHI outage frequency were the best ever; and BGE had its stronger average outage duration or shortest average outage duration ever. 
The benefits of our uniform management model across the utilities, our smart grid initiative and our continued reliability spending are currently paying dividends for our customers. 
Turning to our nonregulated business operations, we had a banner year generations well. Our nuclear fleet has its highest ever capacity factor at 94.6 versus the industry average of 90.4, which allowed us to produce an additional 7 terawatt hours more and approximately $275 million of revenue than if we had just been average. 
We also had the shortest average refueling duration ever just over 22 days versus the industry average of 37 days. 
The fact the entire fleet performed so well against the backdrop of potential plant closures and fighting for ZEC is truly a testament to the professionalism of the workforce, which we all are greatly appreciative of. 
Our gas, hydro and assets also had a good year. Strong energy capture on renewable and power dispatch on our conventional plants. 
At Constellation, the team performed exceptionally well. Our customer renewal rate was 77% for electric and 91% for gas. Equally important, our new business win rate was at 28% last year and our C&I market share grew to 25%. 
Now I'm going to turn the call over to Jack to provide the financial update.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and good morning, everyone. My remarks today will focus on 2016 results, 2017 earnings guidance and updates to a number of our financial disclosures including gross margin. Going forward, the fourth quarter will be when we update key f
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and good morning, everyone. My remarks today will focus on 2016 results, 2017 earnings guidance and updates to a number of our financial disclosures including gross margin. 
Going forward, the fourth quarter will be when we update key financial disclosures and roll our hedge disclosures for the year. 
On Slide 8, as Chris stated, we had a very strong year financially and operationally across the company. For the full year, we delivered adjusted non-GAAP operating earnings of $2.68 per share, near the top end of our original guidance range of $2.40 to $2.70 per share. 
Strong performance above our Utility and Generation businesses drove these results. The appendix contains further detail on both our fourth quarter and full year financial results by operating company on Slides 52 and 53. 
Turning to Slide 9. We expect to deliver full year 2017 adjusted operating earnings of $2.50 to $2.80 per share, with the first quarter in the range of $0.55 to $0.65 per share. Our 2017 guidance range includes a full year contribution from PHI, contributions from the FitzPatrick plants after closing and the partial year impacts of the New York and Illinois ZEC programs that start on April 1 and June 1, respectively. 
The growth in utility earnings primarily reflects continued reliability investments at ComEd, plus higher formulaic allowed ROEs as well as increased rates from the recent distribution rate cases at BGE, ACE and Pepco Maryland. These are partially offset by higher O&M at PECO and BGE related to a return to normal short cost after Comark 2016 as well as higher depreciation and amortization driven by capital expenditures. 
At Exelon Generation, the year-over-year decreases is primarily driven by the impact of hedging into lower energy prices, partially offset by revenues from the New York and Illinois ZEC programs as well as the new taxes CCGTs coming online this summer. More detail on the year-over-year drivers by operating company can be found on the appendix starting on Slide 55. 
On Slide 10, let's turn to our updated multi-year forecast that will cover 2017 to 2020 and provide a refresh of what we shared with you at the Analyst Day. For your convenience, in the appendix we show this updated number side-by-side against the analyst day numbers. 
We will [indiscernible] more than $20 billion into our utilities to the benefits of our customers over the next 4 years, which is a slight increase since Analyst Day. Upside comps from future energy jobs bill in Illinois which will allow ComEd to growth rate base and on an a fair rate of return on energy efficiency investments. We now project rate base growth of 6.5% through 2020. 
On Slide 11 of the $9 billion of rate base growth expected through 2020, approximately 75% is covered on either formula rates or other similar types of mechanisms. These timely recovery mechanisms allow us to make additional investments on the behalf of our customers while supporting our ability to earn our allowed ROE. Where we do not have mechanisms, we will continue to work with stakeholders to enact and implement these types of tools. 
I should also note that following the passage of the Illinois legislation more than 70% of our rate base is decoupled. 
On Slide 12, we showed a trailing 12-month blended transmission distribution earned booked ROE at each of the PHI utilities relative to their allowed ROEs. ROEs at PHI have improved modestly but there's still much work to be done. Legacy Exelon Utilities had a strong 2016, earning 10.5% as a group, helped by favorable weather and lower-than-normal storm activity. 
On a weather normalized basis, the earned returns or ROEs will be closer to 10.1%. Improving the earned ROEs at PHI and sustaining a strong performance of the legacy Exelon Utilities is important to meeting our overall utility earnings growth targets. 
Going forward, we will provide the slide on a quarterly basis to keep you updated on the progress we're making on an earned returns perspective. 
On Slide 13, we have an update on our current rate cases that are still in progress. Since our last update, we have completed 2 of the pending rate cases: The Pepco Maryland case was decided in November and we received a $52.5 million revenue increase. 
In addition, the ComEd annual formula rate filing was settled in December with an increase of $127 million related to approximately $2.4 billion in capital investments made in 2015. Those investments which include $663 million for smart grid related work that help strengthen and modernize the electric system. 
We still have 4 pending rate cases at Pepco and Delmarva. The mine were asking for $216 million in revenues, which reflect recovery on multiple years of smart meter and other capital investments that have been made to improve the reliability of the grid across those jurisdictions. We expect the final ruling on the Delmarva Maryland case in mid-February, with the remaining cases being completed over the summer. More details on the rate cases can be found on Slide 61 through 66 in the appendix. 
Consistent with our previous discussions, we expect to file rate cases in each of the PHI the restrictions again in 2017 as we continue to close the gap between allowed and earned ROEs. 
Slide 14 provides an update on our outlook for utility EPS. The bars are largely the same as an Analyst Day, albeit an angle higher in 2017 and 2020. The increase in 2017 is due to continued cost management efforts and the increase in 2020 is due to ComEd's ROEs and efficiency-related investments. 
With a higher 2017 starting point, we now project strong 6% to 8% utility EPS growth through 2020. 
Turning to Slide 15, we've modified our gross margin disclosures for ExGen. We now included new line that carves out capacity and ZEC revenues. ZEC revenues are the payments Exelon receives in New York and Illinois for the beneficial environmental attributes of nuclear plants. The purpose of this new line item is to clearly call out the portion of our gross margins is more contracted in nature. 
As a result of including ZEC revenues from New York and Illinois, the Fitzpatrick acquisition and the reversal of the shut down decisions of Quad Cities and Clinton. Total gross margin increased by $650 million, $1.05 billion and $1.1 billion in 2017, '18 and '19, respectively. 
Almost all the gross margin changes relate to the fleet updates with changes in power prices adding $50 million in 2018 and costing us $50 million in 2019. 
Turning to Slide 16. On our last earnings call, we announced that we were reducing O&M by $100 million in 2018 and $125 million in 2019 at ExGen, adding to the $400 million of savings regarding taking out of the business. 
The baseline O&M outlook remains the same from last quarter, although the total O&M cost outlook has increased with the addition of the FitzPatrick, Quad Cities and Clinton power stations, which we break out on the slides for your reference. Our baseline capital spend is decreasing through 2020, driven by the proactive investments we've made in our nuclear fleet over the years. These investments have resulted in best-in-class performance that reduce risk for significant unplanned capital spending the future.  On Slide 40, we provide greater detail on these investments and the impact they have had on the nuclear fleet since 2010. 
We continue to run an efficient organization, and we'll always look for ways to reduce costs and run the fleet more cost-effectively while maintaining the highest standards for safety and reliability. 
Turning to Slide 17, ExGen will generate nearly $7 billion of free cash flow through 2020, which is more free cash flow for that time period than what was included in our analyst the disclosure. This is primarily driven by the incremental cash associated with the New York and Illinois ZEC programs, partially offset by the impact of lower power prices in the out there years. As we've said before, we will use ExGen's a free cash flow to fund utility investment and pay down over $3 billion of debt through 2020. 
Turning to Slide 18, we remain committed to maintaining a strong balance sheet and our investment-grade credit rating. We were forecasted to be at 3.3x debt-to-EBITDA at ExGen by the end of 2017 and have a clear path to a long-term target of 3x debt-to-EBITDA. 
As we said before, we will look to retire holding company debt once we've reached that 3x targeted ExGen. 
From a recourse perspective, we are already below the 3x debt-to-EBITDA level at 2.7x as shown here on the slide. This ratio will continue to decline as well with the pay down of debt to reach our consolidated 3x target. The health of our ExGen balance sheet is strong and is continuing to improve. 
Before I turn the call over to Chris, I'd like to spend a few minutes on the potential impacts of tax reform legislation to Exelon, which has been a topic of discussion since the election. 
Research reports and our peers have already reported earnings that discussed the impact sectors to their businesses. Our policy perspective, we think simplifying the tax code and lowering rates is the right objective. We are actively working with our partners at EEI and ENI and on our own to help [indiscernible] the tax design. No legislations has been introduced at this time, so no details on exactly what would be included and how will it be included is available beyond the short discussion of the truck plant or the house footprint. In fact, just last week, senate finance committee Chairman Haas said, he's not planning on using the house legislation as a start deploying point . So the Senate will have its own bill and there's no proposal for that bill at this time. And President Trump's economic team has stated that they will have their own views on tax reform once they are in place. 
At this time, there's no way to know when tax forms package will look like and how long it will take to advance, which leaves us of a mindset that is premature to quantify how tax reform will impact Exelon's financial outlook. We've run a wide range of scenarios to understand high-level impacts of common themes in the house and truck plants. The house blueprint excluding order adjustment provisions will be neutral for our utilities, neutral to positive at the Genco and negative at the holding company due to the elimination of all interest deductibility. 
Order adjustment will be an additional negative at ExGen due to the importation of nuclear fuel and at the utilities would raise the cost of imported handy capital equipment that goes in the rate base. We've seen significant opposition to both the order adjustment and elimination of interest expense deductibility recently leaving the fate of these provisions unclear. 
To the extent the Trump campaign becomes the basis of legislation and the election is made to take interest deductability rather than immediately spend capital additions, it can be meaningfully positive to Exelon's earnings. 
We see a long path until tax policy has clarity. We'll continue to advocate for the best interest of our customers and shareholders as legislation is developed. 
With that, I'll now turn the call back to Chris for his closing remarks.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. This slide -- this next slide should look familiar to you at this point. This is Exelon's value proposition, and we're not wavering from these commitments. Strong utility growth, we expect to grow the rate base at 2.5% annually through 2020
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. This slide -- this next slide should look familiar to you at this point. This is Exelon's value proposition, and we're not wavering from these commitments. Strong utility growth, we expect to grow the rate base at 2.5% annually through 2020 -- or 6.5% -- and cut that -- 6.5% annually through 2020, which converts to EPS growth off our 2017 midpoint of 6% to 8% a year. 
We will continue to look for opportunities to invest in reliability and customer service. ExGen is expected to generate nearly $7 billion of free cash flow through 2020, which is better than we had budgeted at the Analyst Day. 
We will use this free cash flow primarily to invest in the utilities, pay down over $3 billion of debt over the next years, and we will continue to optimize the value of ExGen through best-in-class operating like we saw in 2016, capturing the benefits of our gen-to-load matching strategy and fair compensation for our clean energy assets similar to what we've accomplished in Illinois and New York. 
We remain focused on the balance sheet and are comfortable -- comfortably exceeding our credit metrics targets over the planning horizon. And our capital allocation priorities will remain the same: Regulated utility growth, dividend growth and debt production. 
The leadership team firmly believes we can deliver on these commitments to our shareholders. Our executive compensation is directly tied to these goals, with the long-term components driven by keeping the multi-year earnings targets of the utilities, which ensures we grow this business as we've committed to you, meeting our targets improvements in earned ROEs at the utilities, which ensure we turn around the performance of the PHI utilities and maintain a strong investment-grade credit metrics, which ensures the financial health of the business no matter what the commodity price backdrop is. 
Finally, our long-term compensation will be adjusted point per point  with the 3-year performance relative to the UTY. Meaning, that we are directly in line with long-term shareholders. 
I'm proud of everything this team has accomplished in 2016 and very excited about the plan we have in place for the future. 
So with that, Stephanie, we can open it up for questions.

componenttextpreview: Just a couple quick questions. You guys were pretty thorough. Can you give us an update on where you are on some of the tactical decisions you've made to sell down or exit from certain businesses, both the sell down of the renewables business and the proc
componenttext: Just a couple quick questions. You guys were pretty thorough. Can you give us an update on where you are on some of the tactical decisions you've made to sell down or exit from certain businesses, both the sell down of the renewables business and the process of Mystic?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Greg, it's Jack. I'll take that. So start with the renewables, think it's been widely reported that we've been in the market talking about a joint venture for our renewables business and that process is going well. We want to maintain and stay in that bus
componenttext: Greg, it's Jack. I'll take that. So start with the renewables, think it's been widely reported that we've been in the market talking about a joint venture for our renewables business and that process is going well. We want to maintain and stay in that business as it's important to our overall participation in the energy complex. We do have a significant amount of projects level debt on those projects so there's a thinner equity layer on top of that. So the proceeds while meaningful won't be used for debt production. We expect that to be a very positive event for the company. With respect to the Mystic process, that process continues to be under way. We've had broad interest in those assets as they play a key role in that equal market in downtown Boston. We continue to work with various stakeholders to draw into a conclusion, and we look forward to that having a favorable outcome as well here.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Jack, can you give us into an insight as to why it has taken longer than may be we had initially expected when you first articulated a desire to potentially sell those assets. It was at EEI last year and there was the potential for sort of an event early
componenttext: Jack, can you give us into an insight as to why it has taken longer than may be we had initially expected when you first articulated a desire to potentially sell those assets. It was at EEI last year and there was the potential for sort of an event early in the first quarter, and we still haven't seen that? And then even if you were to get a deal tomorrow given the lack of quorum at the FERC, what are you looking at in terms of realistic time to actually come to a closing of the transaction there?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: So we did openly talked about it after it did leak and figured we get that out there, but there's no fire sale here. We need to take our time and go through the process and make sure we obtain the right value for us and for all involved in it. So working
componenttext: So we did openly talked about it after it did leak and figured we get that out there, but there's no fire sale here. We need to take our time and go through the process and make sure we obtain the right value for us and for all involved in it. So working through, we'll keep you informed when we were at a closure.

componenttext: That's correct. And you'll note with the passage of the Illinois legislation and energy efficiency programs are solid programs so we added the CapEx at ComEd rather subsequently or throughout the curve. I think it's also important to note we have a pretty conservative policy on only putting into our CapEx forecast utilities plants that are fully formed for capital investment. So as time progresses and as we see opportunities to invest on the behalf of our customer, there are opportunities for that rate base and capital budgets to grow in those out there periods.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: So Jonathan, your first comment is correct. We previously were talking about retiring debt at the Genco. Now we see the opportunity once we achieve 3x debt-to-EBITDA to retire debt at the holding company. With respect to the debt retired, we'll  retire at
componenttext: So Jonathan, your first comment is correct. We previously were talking about retiring debt at the Genco. Now we see the opportunity once we achieve 3x debt-to-EBITDA to retire debt at the holding company. With respect to the debt retired, we'll  retire at the holding company. We have a $900 million maturity in 2020 where I think you could see us potentially retire that or some component of that. And we're looking at opportunities with use of proceeds from variety of strategic activities that we have ongoing to address the roughly $600 million of export that's not tied to the mandatory convertibles reissuance of $1.15 billion in '17.

Some would fully formed legislation is already moving for community. That's the case in Connecticut and stakeholder outreach [indiscernible] in [indiscernible].

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. We think Jack did a good job framing up why really premature for us to give point to point. Spent a lot of time on my own with the EEI leadership in D.C. to kind of look at this utility -- this effect on utilities, utility customers and what has happ
componenttext: Yes. We think Jack did a good job framing up why really premature for us to give point to point. Spent a lot of time on my own with the EEI leadership in D.C. to kind of look at this utility -- this effect on utilities, utility customers and what has happened in the '86 tax bill. So there's certain things in regulated space that kind of created a difference. I'm sure a lot of industries turn to say they're different. But surely back in '86, the insurance industry and the utility industry -- regulated utility industry was recognized as an exemption or a different methodology. So that kind of conversation is happening within a process. It's not right to have the debate across the table until we have a bill, but coalescing under Tom's leadership and the EEI executive leadership and board, we're kind of working through those issues. Everybody's look for a lower corporate tax rate. That's an easy one. Jack talked about the probability of the blueprint staying the way it is now versus after the sausage is made is something we'll just have to stay engaged and follow. But you reduce and interest reduction from a utility, and that automatically goes on to the customer. And we got to make sure it's not an unintended tax increase to the customer, and we just have to work through those details.

componenttext: Julien, this is Joe. The programs in New York and Illinois are very similar. They're both based on paying for the environmental attributes based on social cost of carbon. And so the readthrough is that when we are successful in New York, we think it will be very helpful for us initiating and challenge the Illinois legislation.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Julien, this is Joe Nigro. Broadly, we look at our asset portfolio on an annual basis and we look across our nuclear feet into our fossil and renewable fleet. And strategically, you've seen some of the assets that we've divested through time here and I wo
componenttext: Julien, this is Joe Nigro. Broadly, we look at our asset portfolio on an annual basis and we look across our nuclear feet into our fossil and renewable fleet. And strategically, you've seen some of the assets that we've divested through time here and I would tell you it hasn't had a material impact on managing our retail portfolio given that we carry a lot of what I would call optionality in our portfolio with the generation assets and then additionally, when we need to we'll go-to-market to augment with that with the additional products. So we're very comfortable where we are, and we continue to strategically look at our portfolio, if the market is willing to pay for something maybe more than we have value on, that will take that into account and make the decisions necessary, recognizing that we do need to manage -- continue to manage our business. And I'm sorry the question on...

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017

componenttext: Retail growth. We're now -- our C&I business -- as Jeff just mentioned -- as Chris mentioned in the script, we're about 25% of the market share in C&I. Our margins remain stable in that $2 to $4 origination range, and we continue to monitor that very closely. You heard what our renewal rates are and our win rates are and they're in line with what we laid out at the Analyst Day, and we're very comfortable with the plan that we have in place. As we move through 2017, we'll continue to monitor that. But right now, we're very happy with where we are.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, we've given you the volumes and I think previously rolled them out again at EEI, and we're very comfortable with where we are on the volume scale. I would tell you, we continue to see consolidation in the retail market. You see some generation entra
componenttext: Well, we've given you the volumes and I think previously rolled them out again at EEI, and we're very comfortable with where we are on the volume scale. I would tell you, we continue to see consolidation in the retail market. You see some generation entrants that have bought in into these existing entities not really creating normal retail platform so there's really no change there. As you know, we bought a few in the last few years, and we see the consolidation. We'll continue to hunt for those if the opportunity is right, and we see value and it fits our portfolio and what we're trying to achieve with the customers and we will remain disciplined with that. With our acquisition of years ago of Integra's and recently last year with ComEd, we've been very happy with that outcome and the way they've integrated into our portfolio, and we'll continue to look for those type of opportunities.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could comment a little bit on the impact or the impacts of lower load growth and capacity performance in the PGM, upcoming PGM capacity auction. And separately, FERC recently rejected the MISO proposal for a competitive retail solut
componenttext: I was wondering if you could comment a little bit on the impact or the impacts of lower load growth and capacity performance in the PGM, upcoming PGM capacity auction. And separately, FERC recently rejected the MISO proposal for a competitive retail solution in certain zones. One of the criticisms I think for CAD and rejection was that it was not broad enough throughout MISO. I'm just wondering if there's any potential for some kind of broader forward auction system throughout the entire Midwest ISO.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael, it's Joe Nigro. I'll take the first question on PJM, and I'll hand it over to Joe Dominguez to talk the MISO question. For the PJM perspective, there's a lot of money moving pieces. The load came in as was previously announced down about 3.5
componenttext: Yes, Michael, it's Joe Nigro. I'll take the first question on PJM, and I'll hand it over to Joe Dominguez to talk the MISO question. For the PJM perspective, there's a lot of money moving pieces. The load came in as was previously announced down about 3.5 gigawatts or 2% so that wasn't unexpected. We cleared about 27 gigawatts of non-CP supply last year or 16% of what cleared and as you mentioned, that will be 100% CP this year. That's obviously, a positive change when you think about price. There was some movement in the import capabilities. We saw it shrink some into the ComEd zone it is on increased slightly in the Eastern so that has an offsetting effect in those 2 areas. I guess, the big thing is it remains around that 2 biggest variables which are the behavior and as you know, year-over-year, the energy [indiscernible] are down given all of the prices were on the cool last year and then additionally, what the new build is, and we continue to struggle to see how the economics of the new goal works given how margin it is at best with where the market is on a forward basis. So putting that all together, there's a lot of moving pieces. Our long-standing policy is really not to try to forecast, but there's a lot the puts and takes that we're evaluating as we go through this.

componenttext: And Michael, this is Joe Dominguez. The short answer to your question is no, I don't see a likelihood that we will see as a result of this [indiscernible] an expansion of the proposals for what was effectively Southern Illinois and Michigan across all of MISO. I can give a little bit more detail, but the answer is no.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think, historically, what we've done is we've begun a discussion and the first stage of the discussion is establishing recognition that nuclear is the lowest-cost and most reliable share [indiscernible] adoption for our customers. That's where we are in
componenttext: I think, historically, what we've done is we've begun a discussion and the first stage of the discussion is establishing recognition that nuclear is the lowest-cost and most reliable share [indiscernible] adoption for our customers. That's where we are in Pennsylvania. The next stage I think we'll start getting into different solution sets. And you've identified a few, right? So you could look at something that similar to the ZEC programs instead of being adopted. You can include nuclear as a qualifying resources and RPSS and it's way too early for me to handicap where that discussion is going to go. There are a lot of different stakeholders. What's important to us is sinking effectively the first concept, which is that nuclear needs to be treated on a level playing field without nonlimiting resources. That will be the first objective in having that discussion and then I think as we move through this and in subsequent calls, we can talk a little bit more about how we handicap the options and outcomes.

Good morning. My name is Stephanie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Exelon Corporation 2016 Q4 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions]
I would now like to turn the call over to Dan Eggers. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stephanie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our fourth quarter 2016 earnings conference call. Leading the call today are Chris Crane, Exelon's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jack Thayer, Exelon's Chief Financial Off
componenttext:
Thank you, Stephanie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our fourth quarter 2016 earnings conference call. Leading the call today are Chris Crane, Exelon's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jack Thayer, Exelon's Chief Financial Officer. They are joined by other members of Exelon's senior management team, who will be available to answer your questions after our prepared remarks.
We issued our earnings release this morning along with the presentation, both of which can be found in the Investor Relations section of Exelon's website. The earnings release and other matters which we discuss during today's call contain forward-looking statements and estimates that are subject to various risks and uncertainties. Actual results could differ from our forward-looking statements based on factors and assumptions discussed in today's material and comments made during the call. Please refer to today's 8-K and Exelon's other SEC filings for discussions of risk factors and factors that may cause results to differ from management's projections, forecasts and expectations.
Today's presentation also includes references to adjusted operating earnings and other non-GAAP measures. Please refer to the information contained in the appendix of our presentation and our earnings release for reconciliations between non-GAAP measures and the nearest equivalent GAAP measures. 
We've scheduled 45 minutes for today's call. 
I'll turn it now over to Chris Crane, Exelon's CEO.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan, and good morning to all. Thank you for joining us. 2016 was a monumental year for Exelon, and I'm very proud of what we have accomplished. We made great progress in the ongoing transformation of our company while delivering on our commitments
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan, and good morning to all. Thank you for joining us. 2016 was a monumental year for Exelon, and I'm very proud of what we have accomplished. We made great progress in the ongoing transformation of our company while delivering on our commitments. We performed well financially. Our 2016 GAAP earnings at $1.22 and our non-GAAP earnings were $2.68, landing near the top of our original guidance range of $2.40 to $2.70. At the utilities, we benefited from a hot summer and low storm cost. At ExGen, the nuclear fleet had its best performance year on record, and at Constellation, the team executed very, very well. 
In 2016, for the first time, our regulated utility, less the holding company, earnings represented more than half of the total earnings and is consistent with our goal for the utilities to be a growing the majority of our EPS. And we've implemented a dividend growth strategy of 2.5% annually through 2018.
In March, we closed on the acquisition of PHI, adding $8.3 billion to our utility rate base and creating a significant geographic footprint covering the mid-Atlantic region. The integration of PHI is going better than planned, helped by our experience with BGE. We are working our way through the first of the 2 cycles of catch-up rate cases at the PHI utilities. We're seeing additional opportunities to help and improve the business processes and the stakeholder outreach process as we go through those rate cases.
The other banner highlight for 2016 was the creation of the ZEC programs in both New York and Illinois. For years, we have argued that all clean energy resources be treated the same way for their environmental attributes. We are able to work with a wide range of stakeholders in both states to enact programs that compensate these plans for their environmental attributes. As a result of these programs, we plan to continue to operate 5 plants and protect high-paying jobs, preserve needed tax bases in rural communities and maintain irreplaceable, emission-free baseload power production. These programs provide a supplemental cash flow for up to 12 years for some of our most at-risk plants.
The Illinois legislation also provides significant benefit for our customers in energy efficiency, additional renewable generation and to benefit lower-income customers. The program also adds to the earnings visibility at ComEd by implementing a decoupling mechanism, supporting energy efficiency investments where we now will be able to earn on a return on those investments and extending the formula rate to 2022.
In 2016, we also found ways to further grow stable revenue streams. We deployed $5.2 billion of CapEx at the utilities, growing the rate bases by $2 billion, acquired ConEd Solutions and will close the FitzPatrick nuclear plant station this spring. We have completed 9 transmission and distribution rate cases, providing revenue increases of $397 million.
None of these accomplishments would be possible without the remarkable 34,000 employees that work hard every day to keep our power and gas flowing. Our workers donated over 170,000 hours to local nonprofits, and Exelon donated $46 million, both of which were the most ever for Exelon. The commitment to our community is clearly part of who we are and shows our engagement beyond the products we deliver every day.
We also recognize the support of our employees is essential to high-performing work cultures, and that is why Exelon took industry lead on 2 important initiatives in 2016. We expanded our pay leave policies to what are truly the best-in-class, with 16 weeks of maternity leave; 8 weeks for fathers and adoptive parents; and 2 weeks of family leave. We were also the first utility to sign the White House Equal Pay pledge.
Being a good citizen also means supporting our local businesses. In 2016, our spend with female- and minority-owned businesses reached $1.9 billion, over 200% since 2011, and it represents almost 20% of our sourceable spending. The team has done a great job making sure we work with our suppliers across all our communities.
Doing the right thing by our employees and communities is the smart thing for business, and more importantly, it's the right thing to do. We are proud to be leading the industry forward in these fronts.
Turning to operations. Our utilities had a great year. The legacy Exelon utilities continue to perform at top quartile on key operating and customer satisfaction metrics. These are the foundations of a constructive regulatory relationship.
The efforts at PHI before the merger and our intense focus on operations since then have started to show benefits. The color blocks are improving even compared to 2015, although we did get some help from favorable weather in 2016. PHI is still improving. We're encouraged by the gain so far, and we have a plan in place to deliver for our customers and stakeholders. 
The color blocks show a great performance, but this actually is underselling how well we did in 2016. We actually had a number of best evers this year. ComEd, BGE, PECO had their best customer satisfaction ever. ComEd and PHI outage frequency were the best ever, and BGE had its strongest average outage duration -- or shortest average outage duration ever. The benefits of our uniform management model across the utilities, our smart grid initiative and our continued reliability spending are currently paying dividends for our customers.
Turning to our nonregulated business operations. We had a banner year in generation as well. Our nuclear fleet had its highest-ever capacity factor at 94.6 versus the industry average of 90.4, which allowed us to produce an additional 7 terawatt hours more and approximately $275 million of revenue than if we had just been average. We also had the shortest average refueling duration ever, just over 22 days, versus the industry average of 37 days.
The fact the entire fleet performed so well against the backdrop of potential plant closures and fighting for ZECs is truly a testament to the professionalism of the workforce, which we all are greatly appreciative of.
Our gas, hydro and renewable assets also had a good year. Strong energy capture on the renewable and power dispatch on our conventional plants. At Constellation, the team performed exceptionally well. Our customer renewal rate was 77% for electric and 91% for gas. Equally important, our new business win rate was at 28% last year, and our C&I market share grew to 25%.
Now I'm going to turn the call over to Jack to provide a financial update.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and good morning, everyone. My remarks today will focus on 2016 results, 2017 earnings guidance and updates to a number of our financial disclosures, including gross margin. Going forward, the fourth quarter will be when we update key fi
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and good morning, everyone. My remarks today will focus on 2016 results, 2017 earnings guidance and updates to a number of our financial disclosures, including gross margin. Going forward, the fourth quarter will be when we update key financial disclosures and roll our hedge disclosures forward the year. 
On Slide 8, as Chris stated, we had a very strong year financially and operationally across the company. For the full year, we delivered adjusted non-GAAP operating earnings of $2.68 per share, near the top end of our original guidance range of $2.40 to $2.70 per share. Strong performance of both our utility and generation businesses drove these results. The appendix contains further detail on both our fourth quarter and full year financial results by operating company on Slides 52 and 53.
Turning to Slide 9. We expect to deliver full year 2017 adjusted operating earnings of $2.50 to $2.80 per share, with the first quarter in the range of $0.55 to $0.65 per share. Our 2017 guidance range includes a full year contribution from PHI, contributions from the FitzPatrick plants after closing and the partial year impacts of the New York and Illinois ZEC programs that start on April 1 and June 1, respectively.
The growth in utility earnings primarily reflects continued reliability investments at ComEd, plus higher formulaic allowed ROEs as well as increased rates from the recent distribution rate cases at BGE, ACE and Pepco Maryland. These are partially offset by higher O&M at PECO and BGE related to a return to normal storm cost after Coremark [ph] 2016 as well as higher depreciation and amortization driven by capital expenditures.
At Exelon Generation, the year-over-year decrease is primarily driven by the impact of hedging into lower energy prices, partially offset by revenues from the New York and Illinois ZEC programs as well as the new Texas CCGTs coming online this summer. More detail on the year-over-year drivers by operating company can be found on the appendix starting on Slide 55.
On Slide 10, let's turn to our updated multiyear forecast that will cover 2017 to 2020 and provide a refresh of what we shared with you at the Analyst Day. For your convenience, in the appendix, we show these updated numbers side by side against the Analyst Day numbers. 
We will invest more than $20 million into our utilities to the benefit of our customers over the next 4 years, which is a slight increase since Analyst Day. Upside comps from the future energy jobs bill at Illinois, which will allow ComEd to grow rate base and earn a fair rate of return on energy efficiency investments. We now project rate base growth of 6.5% through 2020.
On Slide 11, of the $9 billion of rate base growth expected through 2020, approximately 75% is covered on either formula rates or other similar types of mechanisms. These timely recovery mechanisms allow us to make additional investments on the behalf of our customers while supporting our ability to earn our allowed ROE. Where we do not have mechanisms, we will continue to work with stakeholders to enact and implement these types of tools. I should also note that following the passage of the Illinois legislation, more than 70% of our rate base is decoupled.
On Slide 12, we showed a trailing 12-month blended transmission distribution earned book ROE at each of the PHI utilities relative to their allowed ROEs. ROEs at PHI have improved modestly, but there's still much work to be done. Legacy Exelon utilities had a strong 2016, earning 10.5% as a group, helped by favorable weather and lower-than-normal storm activity. On a weather-normalized basis, the earned returns or ROEs would be closer to 10.1%. Improving the earned ROEs at PHI and sustaining a strong performance of the legacy Exelon utilities will be important to meeting our overall utility earnings growth targets. Going forward, we will provide a slide on a quarterly basis to keep you updated on the progress we're making from an earned returns perspective.
On Slide 13, we have an update on our current rate cases that are still in progress. Since our last update, we have completed 2 of the pending rate cases. The Pepco Maryland case was decided in November, and we received a $52.5 million revenue increase. In addition, the ComEd annual formula rate filing was settled in December with an increase of $127 million related to approximately $2.4 billion in capital investments made in 2015. Those investments, which include $663 million for smart grid-related work, had helped strengthen and modernize the electric system.
We still have 4 pending rate cases at Pepco and Delmarva. Combined, we're asking for $216 million in revenues, which reflect recovery on multiple years of smart meter and other capital investments that have been made to improve the reliability of the grid across those jurisdictions. We expect the final ruling on the Delmarva Maryland case in mid-February, with the remaining cases being completed over the summer. More details on the rate cases can be found on Slide 61 through 66 in the appendix.
Consistent with our previous discussions, we expect to file rate cases in each of the PHI jurisdictions again in 2017 as we continue to close the gap between allowed and earned ROEs. 
Slide 14 provides an update on our outlook for utility EPS. The bars are largely the same as in Analyst Day, albeit $0.05 higher in 2017 and 2020. The increase in 2017 is due to continued cost management efforts, and the increase in 2020 is due to ComEd ROEs and efficiency-related investments. With a higher 2017 starting point, we are now -- we now project strong 6% to 8% utility EPS growth through 2020.
Turning to Slide 15. We've modified our gross margin disclosures for ExGen. We now include a new line that carves out capacity and ZEC revenues. ZEC revenues are the payments Exelon receives in New York and Illinois for the beneficial environmental attributes of our nuclear plants. The purpose of this new line item is to clearly call out the portion of our gross margin that is more contracted in nature. As a result of including ZEC revenues from New York and Illinois, the Fitzpatrick acquisition and the reserve -- reversal of the shutdown decisions of Quad Cities and Clinton, total gross margin increased by $650 million, $1.05 billion and $1.1 billion in 2017, '18 and '19, respectively. Almost all the gross margin changes relate to the fleet updates, with changes in power prices adding $50 million in 2018 and costing us $50 million in 2019.
Turning to Slide 16. On our last earnings call, we announced that we were reducing O&M by $100 million in 2018 and $125 million in 2019 at ExGen, adding to the $400 million of savings we've already taken out of the business. 
The baseline O&M outlook remains the same from last quarter, although the total O&M cost outlook has increased with the addition of the FitzPatrick, Quad Cities and Clinton power stations, which we break out on the slides for your reference. Our baseline capital spend is decreasing through 2020, driven by the proactive investments we've made in our nuclear fleet over the years. These investments have resulted in best-in-class performance and reduced risk for a significant unplanned capital spend in the future. On Slide 40, we provide greater detail on these investments and the impact they have had on the nuclear fleet since 2010.
We continue to run an efficient organization, and we'll always look for ways to reduce costs and run the fleet more cost-effectively while maintaining the highest standards for safety and reliability.
Turning to Slide 17. ExGen will generate nearly $7 billion of free cash flow through 2020, which is more free cash flow for that time period than what was included in our Analyst Day disclosure. This is primarily driven by the incremental cash associated with the New York and Illinois ZEC programs, partially offset by the impacts of lower power prices in the outer years. As we've said before, we will use ExGen's a free cash flow to fund utility investment and pay down over $3 billion of debt through 2020.
Turning to Slide 18. We remain committed to maintaining a strong balance sheet and our investment-grade credit rating. We are forecasted to be at 3.3x debt to EBITDA at ExGen by the end of 2017 and have a clear path to our long-term target of 3x debt to EBITDA. As we have said before, we will look to retire holding company debt once we have reached the 3x target at ExGen.
From a recourse perspective, we are already below the 3x debt-to-EBITDA level at 2.7x, as shown here on the slide. This ratio will continue to decline as well with the paydown of debt to reach our consolidated 3x target. The health of our ExGen balance sheet is strong and is continuing to improve.
Before I turn the call over to Chris, I'd like to spend a few minutes on the potential impacts of tax reform legislation to Exelon, which has been a topic of discussion since the election. Research reports and our peers who have already reported earnings have discussed the impacts to the sector and their businesses. From a policy perspective, we think simplifying the tax code and lowering rates is the right objective. We are actively working with our partners at EEI and NEI and all -- and on our own to helping form the ultimate tax design. No legislation has been introduced at this time, so no details on exactly what will be included or how it will be included is available beyond the short description of the Trump plan or the House Blueprint. In fact, just last week, Senate Finance Committee Chairman Hass said he is not planning on using the House legislation as a starting point. So the Senate will have its own bill, and there's no proposal for that bill at this time. And President Trump's economic team has stated that they will have their own views on tax reform once they're in place.
At this time, there's no way to know what tax reform package will look like and how long it will take to advance, which leaves us of a mind-set that is premature to quantify how tax reform will impact Exelon's financial outlook. We have run a wide range of scenarios to understand high-level impacts of common themes in the House and Trump plans. The House Blueprint, excluding order adjustment provisions, will be neutral for our utilities, neutral to positive at the Genco and negative at the holding company due to the elimination of all interest deductibility.
Order adjustment will be an additional negative at ExGen due to the importation of nuclear fuel and, at the utilities, would raise the cost of imported handy capital equipment that goes in the rate base. We have seen significant opposition to both the border adjustment and elimination of interest expense deductibility recently, leaving the fate of these provisions unclear.
To the extent the Trump campaign becomes the basis of legislation and the election is made to take interest deductibility and -- rather than immediately expense capital additions, it can be meaningfully positive to Exelon's earnings. We see a long path until tax policy has clarity. We'll continue to advocate for the best interest of our customers and shareholders as legislation is developed.
With that, I'll now turn the call back to Chris for his closing remarks.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. This slide -- this next slide should look familiar to you at this point. This is Exelon's value proposition, and we are not wavering from these commitments. Strong utility growth. We expect to grow the rate base at 2.5% annually through 2020
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. This slide -- this next slide should look familiar to you at this point. This is Exelon's value proposition, and we are not wavering from these commitments. Strong utility growth. We expect to grow the rate base at 2.5% annually through 2020 -- 6.5% -- and cut that one right away -- 6.5% annually through 2020, which converts to EPS growth off our 2017 midpoint of 6% to 8% a year. We will continue to look for opportunities to invest in reliability and customer service. ExGen is expected to generate nearly $7 billion of free cash flow through 2020, which is better than we had budgeted at the Analyst Day. We will use this free cash flow primarily to invest in the utilities, pay down over $3 billion of debt over the next years. And we will continue to optimize the value of ExGen through best-in-class operating like we saw in 2016, capturing the benefits of our gen-to-load matching strategy and fair compensation for our clean energy assets, similar to what we've accomplished in Illinois and New York. We remain focused on the balance sheet and are comfortable -- comfortably exceeding our credit metrics targets over the planning horizon. And our capital allocation priorities will remain the same: regulated utility growth, dividend growth and debt reduction. The leadership team firmly believes we can deliver on these commitments to our shareholders. 
Our executive compensation is directly tied to these goals, with the long-term components driven by hitting the multiyear earnings targets of the utilities, which ensures we grow this business as we have committed to you; meeting our targets improvements in earned ROEs at the utilities, which ensure we turn around the performance of the PHI utilities; and maintain a strong investment-grade credit metrics, which ensures the financial health of the business no matter what the commodity price backdrop is. Finally, our long-term compensation will be adjusted point per point  with the 3-year performance relative to the UTY; meaning, that we are directly in line with the long-term shareholders.
I'm proud of everything that this team has accomplished in 2016 and very excited about the plan we have in place for the future. 
So with that, Stephanie, we can open it up for questions.

componenttext: Just a couple quick questions. You guys were pretty thorough. So can you give us an update on where you are on some of the tactical decisions you've made to sell down or exit from certain businesses, both the sell-down of the renewables business and the process at Mystic?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Greg, it's Jack. I'll take that. So I'll start with the renewables. I think it's been widely reported that we have been in the market talking about a joint venture for our renewables business, and that process is going well. We want to maintain and stay i
componenttext: Greg, it's Jack. I'll take that. So I'll start with the renewables. I think it's been widely reported that we have been in the market talking about a joint venture for our renewables business, and that process is going well. We want to maintain and stay in that business as it's important to our overall participation in the energy complex. We do have a significant amount of project-level debt on those projects, so there's a thinner equity layer on top of that. So the proceeds, while meaningful, won't -- will be used for debt reduction. We'd expect that to be a very positive event for the company. With respect to the Mystic process, that process continues to be underway. We've had broad interest in those assets as they play a key role in that equal [ph] market in downtown Boston. We continue to work with the various stakeholders to draw it to a conclusion, and we look forward to that having a favorable outcome as well here.

componenttext: Jack, can you give us any insight as to why it's taken longer than maybe we had initially expected when we -- when you first articulated a desire to potentially sell those assets? It was at EEI last year, and there was the potential for sort of an event early in the first quarter, and we still haven't seen that. And then even if you were to get a deal tomorrow, given the lack of a quorum at the FERC, what are we looking at in terms of realistic timing to actually come to a closing of a transaction there?

componenttext: So we did openly talk about it after it had been leaked and figured we'd get that out there, but there's no fire sale here. So working through it, and we'll keep you informed when we're at a closure.

So as time progresses and as we see opportunities to invest on the behalf of our customer, there's opportunities for that rate base and capital budget to grow in those outer periods.

componenttext: So Jonathan, your first comment is correct. We previously were talking about retiring debt at the Genco. And we're looking at opportunities with use of proceeds from a variety of strategic activities that we have ongoing to address the roughly $600 million of export that's not tied to the mandatory convertibles reissuance of $1.15 billion in '17.

I know you don't want to get into specifics, but just -- if we think about your company and the issues you care most about getting kind of fixed or adjusted, are there any particular ones that you're most focused on kind of addressing of the different factors that you mentioned?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. We think Jack did a good job framing up why it's really premature for us to get point to point. Spent a lot of time on my own with the East EEI leadership in D.C. to kind of look at this utility -- this effect on utilities, utility customers and what
componenttext: Yes. We think Jack did a good job framing up why it's really premature for us to get point to point. Spent a lot of time on my own with the East EEI leadership in D.C. to kind of look at this utility -- this effect on utilities, utility customers and what has happened in the '86 tax bill. So there are certain things in regulated space that kind of create a difference. I'm sure a lot of industries has turned to say they're different. But surely, back in '86, the insurance industry and the utility industry -- regulated utility industry was recognized as an exemption or a different methodology. So that kind of conversation is happening within the process. It's not right to have the debate across the table until we have a bill. But coalescing under Tom Kuhn's leadership and the EEI executive leadership and board, we're kind of working through those issues. Everybody is for a lower corporate tax rate. That's an easy one. Jack talked about the probability of the blueprint staying the way it is now versus after the sausage is made is something we'll just have to stay engaged and follow. But you reduce an interest reduction from a utility, and that automatically goes on to the customer. And we got to make sure it's not an unintended tax increase to the customer, and we just have to work through those details.

componenttext: Julien, this is Joe Nigro. Broadly, we look at our asset portfolio on an annual basis, and we look across our nuclear feet and through our fossil and renewable fleet. And strategically, you've seen some of the assets that we've divested through time here, and I will tell you, it hasn't had a material impact on managing our retail portfolio given that we carry a lot of what I would call optionality in our portfolio with the generation assets. And then additionally, when we need to, we will go to market to augment with additional products. So we're very comfortable where we are, and we continue to strategically look at our portfolio. And if the market is willing to pay for something maybe more than we have value on, that will take that into account and make the decisions necessary, recognizing that we do need to manage -- continue to manage our business. And I'm sorry, the question on...

componenttext: Retail growth. We're now -- our C&I business, as Jack mentioned -- as Chris mentioned in the script, is about -- we're about 25% of the market share in C&I. Our margins remain stable in that $2 to $4 origination range, and we continue to monitor that very closely. We -- you heard what our renewal rates are and our win rates are, and they're in line with what we laid out in the Analyst Day, and we're very comfortable with the plan that we have in place. As we move through 2017, we'll continue to monitor that. But right now, we're very happy with where we are.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, you -- we've given you the volumes. And I think previously, we rolled them out again at EEI. And we're very comfortable with where we are on the volume scale. I would tell you, we continue to see consolidation in the retail market. You see some gene
componenttext: Well, you -- we've given you the volumes. And I think previously, we rolled them out again at EEI. And we're very comfortable with where we are on the volume scale. I would tell you, we continue to see consolidation in the retail market. You see some generation entrants that have bought into these existing entities not really creating normal retail platform. So there's really no change there. As you know, we've bought a few in the last few years, and we see the consolidation. We'll continue to hunt for those if the opportunity is right and we see value and it fits our portfolio and what we're trying to achieve with the customers, and we'll remain disciplined with that. With our acquisition a few years ago of Integrys and, recently last year, with ConEd, we've been very happy with that outcome and the way they have integrated into our portfolio. And we'll continue to look for those type of opportunities.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Weinstein with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Weinstein with Credit Suisse.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could comment a little bit on the impact or the impacts of lower load growth and capacity performance in the PJM -- upcoming PJM capacity auctions. And separately, FERC recently rejected the MISO proposal for a competitive retail so
componenttext: I was wondering if you could comment a little bit on the impact or the impacts of lower load growth and capacity performance in the PJM -- upcoming PJM capacity auctions. And separately, FERC recently rejected the MISO proposal for a competitive retail solution in certain zones. One of the criticisms, I think, FERC had in the rejection was that it was not broad enough throughout MISO. I'm just wondering if there's any potential for some kind of broader forward auction system throughout the entire Midwest ISO.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. Michael, it's Joe Nigro. I'll take the first question on PJM, and then I'll hand it off to Joe Dominguez to talk a little bit about the MISO question. From a PJM perspective, there's a lot of moving pieces. The load came in as was previously announce
componenttext: Yes. Michael, it's Joe Nigro. I'll take the first question on PJM, and then I'll hand it off to Joe Dominguez to talk a little bit about the MISO question. From a PJM perspective, there's a lot of moving pieces. The load came in as was previously announced, down about 3.5 gigawatts or 2%. So that wasn't unexpected. We cleared about 27 gigawatts of non-CP supply last year or 16% of what cleared. And as you mentioned, that will be 100% CP this year. That's obviously a positive change when you think about price. There was some movement in the import capabilities. We saw it shrink some into the ComEd zone, and we saw it increase slightly into Eastern map. So that has an offsetting effect in those 2 areas. I guess the big thing is it remains around the 2 biggest variables, which are the [indiscernible] behavior and, as you know, year-over-year, the energy rents are down given how low the prices were on the pool last year and then, additionally, what the new build is. And we continue to struggle to see how the economics of that new build works given how marginal it is at best with where the market is on a forward basis. So putting that all together, there's a lot of moving pieces. Our long-standing policy is really not to try to forecast that, but there's a lot of puts and takes that we're evaluating as we go through this.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: And Michael, this is Joe Dominguez. The short answer to your question is no, I don't see a likelihood that we will see, as a result of this FERC order, an expansion of the proposals for what was effectively Southern Illinois and Michigan across all of MIS
componenttext: And Michael, this is Joe Dominguez. The short answer to your question is no, I don't see a likelihood that we will see, as a result of this FERC order, an expansion of the proposals for what was effectively Southern Illinois and Michigan across all of MISO. I could give a little bit more detail, but the answer is no.

componenttext: Okay. Got it. And then, Joe, can you just real quick handicap Pennsylvania maybe from a potential timing or when we can see something? Are we looking at an adjustment to the ARC Gas to include the nuclear? Or is it more of a function of sort of a similar ZEC-type program?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think historically, what we have done is we have begun a discussion. And the first stage of the discussion is establishing a recognition that nuclear is the lowest-cost and most reliable 0-carbon option for our customers. That's where we are in Pennsylv
componenttext: I think historically, what we have done is we have begun a discussion. And the first stage of the discussion is establishing a recognition that nuclear is the lowest-cost and most reliable 0-carbon option for our customers. That's where we are in Pennsylvania. The next stage, I think we'll start getting into different solution sets, and you've identified a few, right? So you can look at something that's similar to the ZEC programs instead of being adopted. You can include nuclear as a qualifying resources in RPSs. And it's way too early for me to handicap where that discussion is going to go. There are a lot of different stakeholders. What's important to us is the sinking effect of the first concept, which is that nuclear needs to be treated on a level playing field without the non-emitting resources. That will be the first objective in having that discussion. And then I think as we move through this and in subsequent calls, we could talk a little bit more about how we handicap the options and outcomes.
