componenttext: And you wouldn't necessarily take on -- I'll skip [ph] a little further acquisitive expansions and additional organic. And maybe that's a good kind of segue into thinking about what kinds of targets are you thinking about on a volumetric basis for the volumes in aggregate as we move through time.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, you -- we've given you the volumes. And I think previously, we rolled them out again at EEI. And we're very comfortable with where we are on the volume scale. I would tell you, we continue to see consolidation in the retail market. You see some gene
componenttext: Well, you -- we've given you the volumes. And I think previously, we rolled them out again at EEI. And we're very comfortable with where we are on the volume scale. I would tell you, we continue to see consolidation in the retail market. You see some generation entrants that have bought into these existing entities not really creating normal retail platform. So there's really no change there. As you know, we've bought a few in the last few years, and we see the consolidation. We'll continue to hunt for those if the opportunity is right and we see value and it fits our portfolio and what we're trying to achieve with the customers, and we'll remain disciplined with that. With our acquisition a few years ago of Integrys and, recently last year, with ConEd, we've been very happy with that outcome and the way they have integrated into our portfolio. And we'll continue to look for those type of opportunities.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Weinstein with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Weinstein with Credit Suisse.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could comment a little bit on the impact or the impacts of lower load growth and capacity performance in the PJM -- upcoming PJM capacity auctions. And separately, FERC recently rejected the MISO proposal for a competitive retail so
componenttext: I was wondering if you could comment a little bit on the impact or the impacts of lower load growth and capacity performance in the PJM -- upcoming PJM capacity auctions. And separately, FERC recently rejected the MISO proposal for a competitive retail solution in certain zones. One of the criticisms, I think, FERC had in the rejection was that it was not broad enough throughout MISO. I'm just wondering if there's any potential for some kind of broader forward auction system throughout the entire Midwest ISO.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. Michael, it's Joe Nigro. I'll take the first question on PJM, and then I'll hand it off to Joe Dominguez to talk a little bit about the MISO question. From a PJM perspective, there's a lot of moving pieces. The load came in as was previously announce
componenttext: Yes. Michael, it's Joe Nigro. I'll take the first question on PJM, and then I'll hand it off to Joe Dominguez to talk a little bit about the MISO question. From a PJM perspective, there's a lot of moving pieces. The load came in as was previously announced, down about 3.5 gigawatts or 2%. So that wasn't unexpected. We cleared about 27 gigawatts of non-CP supply last year or 16% of what cleared. And as you mentioned, that will be 100% CP this year. That's obviously a positive change when you think about price. There was some movement in the import capabilities. We saw it shrink some into the ComEd zone, and we saw it increase slightly into Eastern MACT. So that has an offsetting effect in those 2 areas. I guess the big thing is it remains around the 2 biggest variables, which are the bidding behavior and, as you know, year-over-year, the energy rents are down given how low the prices were on the pool last year and then, additionally, what the newbuild is. And we continue to struggle to see how the economics of that newbuild works given how marginal it is at best with where the market is on a forward basis. So putting that all together, there's a lot of moving pieces. Our long-standing policy is really not to try to forecast that, but there's a lot of puts and takes that we're evaluating as we go through this.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: And Michael, this is Joe Dominguez. The short answer to your question is no, I don't see a likelihood that we will see, as a result of this FERC order, an expansion of the proposals for what was effectively Southern Illinois and Michigan across all of MIS
componenttext: And Michael, this is Joe Dominguez. The short answer to your question is no, I don't see a likelihood that we will see, as a result of this FERC order, an expansion of the proposals for what was effectively Southern Illinois and Michigan across all of MISO. I could give a little bit more detail, but the answer is no.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017

componenttext: At this time, we have reached the allotted time for questions. Our final question comes from Shar Pourreza with Guggenheim Partners.

componenttext: So just real quick on this $0.32 that you're now guiding on ZECs and FitzPatrick. Can you -- are you embedding any sort of synergies of owning Nine Mile and FitzPatrick within the same portfolio? Or you're still kind of looking at this opportunity?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017

Obviously, given its proximity to our Nine Mile unit, we anticipate that there may be opportunities as we get in there and optimize the operations.

componenttext: Okay. Got it. And then, Joe, can you just real quick handicap Pennsylvania maybe from a potential timing or when we can see something? Are we looking at an adjustment to the ARC Gas to include the nuclear? Or is it more of a function of sort of a similar ZEC-type program?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think historically, what we have done is we have begun a discussion. And the first stage of the discussion is establishing a recognition that nuclear is the lowest-cost and most reliable 0-carbon option for our customers. That's where we are in Pennsylv
componenttext: I think historically, what we have done is we have begun a discussion. And the first stage of the discussion is establishing a recognition that nuclear is the lowest-cost and most reliable 0-carbon option for our customers. That's where we are in Pennsylvania. The next stage, I think we'll start getting into different solution sets, and you've identified a few, right? So you can look at something that's similar to the ZEC programs that have been adopted. You can include nuclear as a qualifying resources in RPSs. And it's way too early for me to handicap where that discussion is going to go. There are a lot of different stakeholders. What's important to us is the sinking effect of the first concept, which is that nuclear needs to be treated on a level playing field without the non-emitting resources. That will be the first objective in having that discussion. And then I think as we move through this and in subsequent calls, we could talk a little bit more about how we handicap the options and outcomes.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Josephine, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Exelon Corporation 2017 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Josephine, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Exelon Corporation 2017 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Dan Eggers, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Josephine. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our first quarter 2017 earnings conference call. Leading the call today are Chris Crane, Exelon's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jack Thayer, Exelon's Chief Financial Of
componenttext:
Thank you, Josephine. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our first quarter 2017 earnings conference call. 
Leading the call today are Chris Crane, Exelon's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jack Thayer, Exelon's Chief Financial Officer. 
They're joined by other members of Exelon's senior management team, who will be available to answer your questions following our prepared remarks. 
We issued our earnings release this morning, along with the presentation, both of which can be found in the Investor Relations section of Exelon's website. 
The earnings release and other matters, which we'll discuss during today's call, contain forward-looking statements and estimates that are subject to various risks and uncertainties. Actual results could differ from our forward-looking statements based on factors and assumptions discussed in today's material and comments made during this call. Please refer to today's 8-K and Exelon's other SEC filings for discussions of risk factors and factors that may cause results to differ from management's projections, forecasts and expectations. 
Today's presentation also includes references to adjusted operating earnings and other non-GAAP measures. Please refer to the information contained in the appendix of our presentation and our earnings release for reconciliations between the non-GAAP measures and the nearest equivalent GAAP measures. We've scheduled 45 minutes for today's call. 
I'll now turn the call over to Chris Crane, Exelon's CEO.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan, and good morning, and thank you all for joining us. We're off to a great start for 2017. In March, we marked our one year anniversary of the merger between Exelon and Pepco Holdings. Since the close, PHI has successfully executed on merge
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan, and good morning, and thank you all for joining us. 
We're off to a great start for 2017. In March, we marked our one year anniversary of the merger between Exelon and Pepco Holdings. 
Since the close, PHI has successfully executed on merger commitments, achieved synergy savings and made significant progress toward full integration. 
We also continue to work hard on the regulatory front. Since the beginning of the year, PHI closed out the Delmarva Maryland rate case and reached a settlement for our electric and gas rate case in Delaware. We're now down to just Pepco DC cases from our first plant cycle of rate case filings. 
That said, our regulatory team has already started the second cycle of rate cases at Pepco Maryland and Asus plant. 
At ExGen, we completed the acquisition of FitzPatrick power plant, representing the 25th nuclear reactor where we have ownership stake. We welcome the new employees to the Exelon family. 
We also announced the Exelon Generation renewable joint venture, which is allowing us to recycle capital at valuation meaningfully above the value implied for our ExGen at our current share price. The JV allows us to make even faster progress on our debt reduction goals without diminishing our commitment to renewable power. 
We continue to focus on the legal challenges to the Zero Emission Credits, or ZEC, in New York and Illinois. We remain confident that our arguments will prevail. We'll cover these points in more detail in the call, but I wanted to highlight what we have done while staying focused on the day-to-day operations. 
As shown on Slide 5, on a GAAP basis, we've earned $1.07 versus $0.19 a share last year and on an operating basis, we earned $0.65 versus $0.68 last year, which puts us at the top of our $0.55 to $0.65 range and above consensus of $0.62. 
Moving to Slide 6. Our first operation -- our first quarter operations report was strong. Our color block charts highlight operating performance and customer satisfaction for the utilities. 
Legacy Exelon Utilities remain almost entirely first quartile. PECO actually had its best customer satisfaction rating ever during first quarter. BGE experienced the best ever CAIDI and SAIFI performance of all time. At PHI, we're encouraged by the progress we are making and our customers are seeing the benefits. 
For example, by using a common lockout tug out process, a procedure that has established a zone of protection while restoring equipment, we were able to send over 400 employees and contractors from BGE, ComEd and PECO to support the storm restoration at Delmarva during winter Storm Stellar. 
As a result, Delmarva customers had their power restored 2 days sooner. Our thanks to everybody that helped accomplishing that speedy recovery. 
The power of Exelon Utilities platform is significant benefit to our customers. We continue to improve upon these metrics to meet reliability commitments we have made to provide better service to our customers. 
The nuclear team had a great quarter also. They completed 3 refueling outages and achieved the capacity factor of 94%. 
They had also had the fastest refueling outage ever for Calver nuclear station 2, running 20 days. 
In the Power business, we realized renewable energy capture rate of nearly 96% and a power dispatch match of 94% over 99%. 
Our 2 newbuilds, CCGT in Texas, have both achieved first flyer and are now selling test power onto the grid. The state-of-the-art plants, which are totally nearly 2,200 megawatts are on budget, on schedule for full commercial operations in the second quarter. We expect that they will be ready to participate in Texas this summer. 
At Constellation, our highly hedged portfolio in 2017, mitigates the impact of weaker power prices and lower load given the mild winter weather. 
Even in this recent low volatility environment, our C&I business has been able to hold onto margins and keep customer renewables. 
On Slide 7, we view 2016 is a great success in delivering on our commitments and preserving some of our at risk nuclear units by securing compensation for the clean energy attributes. 
For 2017, we're focused on executing on these gains we made last year, and more importantly, affirming the ZEC programs in the quarter. 
In New York, litigation is further along at this point. On March 29, the judge in New York Federal Court heard oral arguments on our motions to dismiss. We made strong arguments at this hearing and believe the law is clearly on our side. 
We do ask that -- we do get asked when we expect a decision, but the judge is not giving a specific timeline for deadline to issue for order. If we prevail in a motion to dismiss, we would expect the other side to appeal that decision.  If the judge denies our motion to dismiss, we'll move forward with the case as planned. 
As I said, previously, we're confident in the strength of our case. 
In Illinois, 2 groups of plants have challenge the ZEC and federal court in the cases of being before 1 judge. The plan is filed for preliminary injunction on March 31. We intervened in that case on April 10, and we filed motions to dismiss. The judge has held a preliminary injunction motion while he receives full briefing on the motion to dismiss. He will then determine whether there is a legal basis to go forward. That briefing will be completed by May 15 and the judge is scheduled to inform the parties of his intention on May 22nd. 
In the interim, we start recognizing ZEC revenues in New York on April 1. In Illinois, the utilities have filed tariffs to begin collecting that ZEC payments on June 1. We don't expect the actual ZEC procurement process in Illinois to conclude until later in the fall. We remain confident that the ZEC programs will be upheld in the courts to the benefits of the state, the communities and these valuable resources. 
As we have discussed last year in our carbon policy principles, we see state programs as an essential mechanism until have more work the same federal policy that values clean baseload generation. Energy Secretary Perry, recent Director to look at the importance of preserving baseload generation is early but encouraging. We appreciate the secretary's focus to promote and needed market reforms to compensate these assets. We will support the DOE's effort as they move forward. 
Turning to the upcoming PJM auction. We understand the investment community is paying close attention particularly after the disappointing MISO capacity auction results. Joe Nigro is available to answer more detailed questions if you have them. But let me share a few thoughts around the auction. 
Through the positive, we're going to 100% CP for the first time which will put a higher performance burden on the entire fleet. We still think this should lead to a more responsible bidding given the higher risk around nonperformance. The C numbers or the import capacity into ComEd and EMAC LDAs have tightened this year versus last year. 
The tightening can flag more constrained market conditions than last year in these zones, which could help in separation. So the negative PJM load is demand forecast, again, for this auction and FERC approved seasonal aggregation that will allow products to otherwise would not clear to participate 100% in CP world. 
Finally, we have the risk of more uneconomic generation being built primary in Pennsylvania and Ohio. 
These drivers are important, but we still expect clearing prices to come down to bidding behavior. 
The UFC has bid our assets in recent auctions to reflect the underlying economic needs of the individual plants, which in turn has led to some of our plants not clearing. You should expect us to bid our assets in the same responsible fashion in this next upcoming auction. 
Now let the turn the call over to Jack to walk through the numbers.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and good morning, everyone. My remarks today will cover our first quarter results, an overview of our current rate cases and update of our gross margin disclosures and a review of some the events that occurred this quarter. Turning to
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and good morning, everyone. My remarks today will cover our first quarter results, an overview of our current rate cases and update of our gross margin disclosures and a review of some the events that occurred this quarter. 
Turning to Slide 8. We had a strong quarter financially and operationally across the company. For the first quarter, we delivered adjusted non-GAAP operating earnings of $0.65 per share at the top of our guidance range of $0.55 to $0.65 per share. This compares to $0.68 per share for the first quarter of 2016. 
Exelon's utilities delivered a combined $0.47 per share. Versus our plant, the utility results were impacted by unfavorable weather at PECO and PHI, which was more than offset by O&M timing across all the utilities. With 70% of our distribution rate base and decoupled jurisdictions including ComEd starting in 2017, we experienced less volatility on our utility earnings from record warm weather in January and February than if we did not have these programs. To help with us in context, this is the first time in 146 years when there was no snow in the ground in Chicago for both January and February. 
Across PJM, January and February were the warmest on record since data started being collected in 1950. 
Generation had a strong quarter relative to plan, earning $0.18 per share. We had good performance from our nuclear assets with better capacity factors than budgeted and our Constellation team, once again, delivered strong results despite weak power prices and low volatility. 
Turning to Slide 9. The $0.65 per share in the first quarter this year was $0.03 per share lower than the first quarter of 2016. To the positive, we have full quarter of contribution from PHI relative to only 8 days last year, which added $0.09. The other utilities benefited from rate relief and higher rate base, partly offset at PECO with even milder weather than last year. 
ExGen was down year-over-year primarily on the known impacts of lower capacity prices and power price realization as well as more plant refueling outages. 
Turning to Slide 10. We are reaffirming our full year guidance range of $2.50 to $2.80 per share. We expect to deliver operating earnings of $0.45 to $0.55 in the second quarter compared with $0.65 last year. Our second quarter results will include contributions from the FitzPatrick plant and the impacts of the New York ZEC program that started on April 1. 
The Illinois ZEC legislation will go into effect on June 1 and plant procurement is expected to occur later this fall. Plans receiving contracts with recognized revenues retroactive to the June 1 effective date. 
Moving to Slide 11. Our utilities continue to execute well, delivering stronger returns in the quarter. Looking at the trailing 12-month booked ROEs, we saw nice improvements even relative to what we showed last quarter. 
At PHI, we saw all of the utilities restrict gains with some help coming as revenues from the first cycle of rate cases are starting to flow through to results. 
For the legacy Exelon Utilities, we continue to see strong earned ROEs over 10% that lift the consolidated Exelon utilities platform to nearly 10%, including PHI. 
We have plenty of work to do at utilities and with our regulators to keep improving the product we're delivering to our customers. But we're happy with where the overall business is performing. We're, obviously, pleased with our earned ROEs are trending, but I want to remind you that there will be variability in the [indiscernible] ROEs that are different utilities as we go forward. The timing of rate case implementation, weather comparability and in-service states will all impact results. 
We think the ability to earn strong ROEs and the plan that we have in place at PHI to improve their ROEs will be the recipe for our future success. 
On Slide 12, we have an update on our rate cases. Since our fourth quarter call, we have closed out the the Delmarva Maryland case with a revenue increase of $38 million. We've also reached unanimous settlements in our Delmarva Delaware electric and gas cases for $31.5 million and $4.9 million, respectively. And would expect commission approval during the second quarter. 
From our first cycle of plant rate cases, we're now down just to the Pepco D.C. case, where we expect the Commission decision later in July. We're proud of the hard work from our utilities and regulatory teams. These efforts are helping to get PHI's revenues and book ROEs back on course while we simultaneously improve performance for our customers. 
As we've shared with you many times before, we've always viewed the turnaround in PHI earned ROEs as a two rate cycle process. To that end, we bought our second rate cases at A's and Pepco Maryland this quarter. 
Combined with the outstanding cases from the first cycle that I previously mentioned, we are currently asking for $252 million in revenues, which reflect recovery on multiple years of capital investments that have been made to improve the reliability off the grid across these jurisdictions. We expect the final ruling on Pepco Maryland and ACE likely  in Q4 2017 and first quarter of 2018, respectively. We plan to file a second cycle of cases in most if not all of PHI's jurisdiction in 2017 with all completed by the end of 2018, putting us in a position to earn between 9% and 10% ROEs in 2019. More details on the rate case is our schedules to be found on Slide 29 through 36 in the appendix. 
Slide 13 provides our gross margin update for ExGen. In 2017, total gross margin is flat to our last disclosure. 
During the quarter, we executed on $150 million of power new business and $50 million of nonpower new business. We're highly hedged for the rest of this year and are well balanced on our generation load matching strategy. 
Total gross margin decreased in the first quarter by $50 million in both 2018 and 2019 due to the impact of price changes on our portfolio. We ended the quarter approximately 12% to 15% behind our ratable hedging program in 2018 and 8% to 11% behind ratable in 2019 when considering cross commodity hedges. The majority of our length is concentrated in the Midwest to align fundamental view of spot market upside at NiHub. Although we have increased our links in other regions as well. 
We're comfortable with being more open when we look at market fundamentals. For example, forward regional natural gas prices today are over $1 per MMBtu higher than they realized last year yet the forward for power are only about $1 per megawatt higher. We do not believe that is a sustainable situation. 
To that point, I should note the power prices have risen since the start of the second quarter and have reversed about half of the first quarter price declines. 
On Slide 14, we have highlighted some key recent events. On March 31, 2017, we executed on the creation of the Exelon Generation renewables JV, which will provide us with $400 million of pretax cash. 
Including allocated debt that puts total JV enterprise value at approximately $1.7 billion. The price implies an EV to EBITDA multiple over 10x and a dollar per kW value over $1,200. 
The JV consists of 1,296 megawatts of renewable generation capacity, which is about 35% of our renewables output and has an average contract life of 14 years. The JV structure provides the option to drop-down contractable renewable assets from our portfolio in the future. The proceeds from this sale will be used to accelerate our deleveraging strategy. 
Also on March 31, we closed on the acquisition of the FitzPatrick Nuclear Station from Entergy, which adds 838 megawatts of nuclear capacity to our portfolio. 
As you know, the FitzPatrick plant is part of the New York ZEC program, and we received ZEC payments for the next 12 years, which started on April 1. The plant is now operated by Exelon, and I'm happy to report, we had a clean cut over FitzPatrick on to the Exelon platform. We're excited to have the FitzPatrick employees as part of the Exelon family. 
Our Exelon Generation Texas partnership, commonly referred to as EGTP, is a portfolio of 3,476 megawatts of gas generation in Texas. In 2014, we raised $675 million of nonrecourse project finance for the assets, which currently has a balance of approximately $650 million. With a downturn in our account power markets, these assets have been under pressure with a debt rating at a discount face value for some time and the plants struggling to generate adequate cash flows. 
Due to the combination of challenge cash flows and our decision not to inject additional equity, we have come to terms with the lenders to pursue an orderly sale of the assets on their behalf. 
The modest current earnings and all the debt are still included in our financial outlook. However, we see the ultimate exit from these assets be accretive to our EPS and debt-to-EBITDA starting in 2018. 
In light of the process, we are not in the position to expand further on this transaction. 
Finally during the quarter, we decided to discontinue the sales process of the Mystic 8 and 8 assets. We were exploring the sale of these assets as a direct result of interest received from the potential buyers. During the sale process, we ran into some issues with the fuel supply agreement that needs to be addressed and as we've said, we would only transact when we realize the price greater than our whole value. Our continuing to own this assets does not impact our commitments on our debt-to-EBITDA target and debt reduction plans that we already shared with you. 
Turning to Slide 15, we remain committed to maintaining a strong balance sheet in our investment-grade credit rating. We're forecasting to be 3.2x debt-to-EBITDA at ExGen by the end of 2017 and have a clear path to our long-term target of 3x debt-to-EBITDA. 
On a recourse debt basis, we're already well ahead of our target and taking into account the sale of EGTP, we would be on target overall. As we said before, we will look to retire debt once we would reach 3x target at ExGen. 
I'll now turn the call back to Chris for his closing remarks.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. This brings us back to our value proposition shown on Slide 16, which looks familiar. It is unchanged from our last earnings report, and we remain committed to these points. We continue to grow the utility rate base at 6.5% annually through
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. This brings us back to our value proposition shown on Slide 16, which looks familiar. It is unchanged from our last earnings report, and we remain committed to these points. We continue to grow the utility rate base at 6.5% annually through 2020 and regulated EPS by 6% to 8% annually through 2020. We continue to use free cash flow generated at ExGen to fund incremental equity needs of the utilities of $2.5 billion and pay down approximately $3 billion of debt over the next 4 years at ExGen and the holding company. We're focused on optimizing value for ExGen business by seeking fair compensation for our carbon-free generation fleet, closing on economic plants, opportunistically selling assets where it makes sense to accelerate our debt reduction plan and maximizing value to our gen-to-load matching strategy. We continue to focus on sustaining strong investment-grade credit metrics and grow our dividend in a consistent, visible manner. 
Thank you for your interest. And we're now ready for questions.

componenttextpreview: Okay. Second question, and maybe it's not something you're able to really engage with me on the call on, but one of the reasons why I think the stock is underperformed is because people are looking, obviously, you've had a little bit of softness in the '1
componenttext: Okay. Second question, and maybe it's not something you're able to really engage with me on the call on, but one of the reasons why I think the stock is underperformed is because people are looking, obviously, you've had a little bit of softness in the '18, '19 curves, you already told us that bounced a little bit but people are looking forward to sort of 2020 role coming this fall and looking at the open -- theoretically, open position and worried about the capacity market print and thinking well, 2020 is going to be another down year. So I don't know if you can comment on how that looks today and also how that dovetails with what you continue to do vis-a-vis debt reduction at ExGen. Because while the balance sheet looks like it's an absolute a great shape today, its EBITDA keeps going south, sort of the bar keeps going up every year in terms of what you are doing with your cash flow to keep it at that level of leverage.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017
componenttextpreview: A couple thoughts, Greg. One, I think it's probably -- the liquidity in the market, it's premature to forecast our 2020 ExGen earnings. But one thing to keep in context. On a recourse basis, by 2020, we'll have $4 billion of debt. That is the most pristin
componenttext: A couple thoughts, Greg. One, I think it's probably -- the liquidity in the market, it's premature to forecast our 2020 ExGen earnings. But one thing to keep in context. On a recourse basis, by 2020, we'll have $4 billion of debt. That is the most pristine balance sheet, I think, in the sector. So from a strength perspective with the balance sheet and ability to deal with the cyclicality of markets, I think we're well positioned. Our fundamental perspective would be that as liquidity returns to the market price are going up across and our hedging approach and the link that we're carrying relative to ratable is demonstrative of that. So I think it's meaningfully premature to be trading on 2020 and in 2017.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017

componenttext: Your next question comes from Jonathan Arnold with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017
componenttextpreview: A question on -- you mentioned, I think, that you would be bidding the units in the PJM auction in the same, I think, you said responsible fashion. Can you give us an insight into what you see is different in the PJM auction set up with respect to say, in
componenttext: A question on -- you mentioned, I think, that you would be bidding the units in the PJM auction in the same, I think, you said responsible fashion. Can you give us an insight into what you see is different in the PJM auction set up with respect to say, in the quad, which has the ZEC and Clinton which, obviously, clear that the low price in MISO. Is there any -- anything we should be thinking about as we sort of compare those 2 situations?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good morning. It's Joe Nigro. I'll take that question, and answer. And as you know, I'll start by saying we have a long-standing practice of really not discussing our bidding strategy around the capacity auction and where we think it will clear. I think t
componenttext: Good morning. It's Joe Nigro. I'll take that question, and answer. And as you know, I'll start by saying we have a long-standing practice of really not discussing our bidding strategy around the capacity auction and where we think it will clear. I think there is one thing though we have to take into account at this timing of the 2 auctions. And so MISO auction was for June of this year through May of next year and the PJM auction, obviously, is much further out in the curve. When you think about the operation for the plant and if you'll fuel loaded in the core at Clinton, for example, that plant was going to continue to operate during that period. What I will say about Quad Cities in the bidding is we're going to continue to remain responsible in the way we bid our capacity, reflecting the underlying economics of our plant, and that's consistent with what we've done with past auctions. I think the major question with this auction continues to be, as Chris mentioned, bidding behavior from the existing generation as well as the discipline associated with newbuild. As it relates to existing facilities, we continue to see economically challenged plans that have cleared previous auctions. And in addition to that, we see the economics the newbuilds being margin. In the last auction, we cleared about 27 gigawatts of base capacity, which was about 16% of the total procurement. And it remains to be seen how that 27 gigawatts will participate in this auction, but the big variable, as I mentioned, will continue to be the bidding of all the plants, and we will remain disciplined in that regard with all of our facilities.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017

componenttext: Okay. And then could I also ask on a yes, I guess, topical issue today, but can you quantify at all or describe your exposure to Westinghouse as a supplier presumably in the fuel business primarily and how we should -- is there any concerns you have with regard to the bankruptcy?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017

componenttext: It's something that we follow closely, not only as a supplier, but for the industry. We have reviewed our positions that we have commercially with them. We're not concerned at this time, but we'll continue to watch it closely. Fuel fabrication, we continue to see that as an ongoing entity in the services business, we continue to gain support, see that is an ongoing entity. None of us know how it's going to shake out yet, but we have minimal exposure there.

What could come out of DOE?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017
componenttextpreview: Steve, let me start off and talk a little about the technical conference over the last couple days. There are 3 buckets of issues that I think I look at. One is carbon pricing on the market and what FERC can do to facilitate the states who are interested
componenttext: Steve, let me start off and talk a little about the technical conference over the last couple days. There are 3 buckets of issues that I think I look at. One is carbon pricing on the market and what FERC can do to facilitate the states who are interested in doing that. The second bucket would be the Mopar issues that's PJM's grid 2020 [indiscernible] and the third bucket are energy reforms. And so I think all three of these things are implied as well in connection with the secretary. Let me talk about the three. First, we think there was a constructive discussion around carbon. One of the issues that has limited the ability of states to incorporate aggressive pricings 2between the states and I think there was good discussion around what FERC can do to address that problem. There is, I think, you'll agree if you saw the technical conference growing recognition that putting carbon explicitly in the market is something that would address a lot of these issues. And there's a growing receptivity to that. The issue of the Mopar's, that's where I think it most directly addresses the state ZEC programs and the RAC programs. The New England proposal doesn't deal with existing baseload generation or existing generation of any kind frankly, and that's consistent with FERC president. And so that template wouldn't have any effect on the safe programs, but PJM proposal does, however, deal with existing resources. And we have not historically supported that proposal. We recognize PJM has made some important changes, and those were talked about that the technical conference. The issue with the Mopar from our perspective is that it is a distraction from some unfinished work that we believe FERC and PJM ought to get to first. Unfortunately, it has become a little bit of a tempest and the teapot in a sense that there's a false narrative out there challenges to the IPP sector are driven by ZEC and the REC policies when in fact a number of our colleagues in the business side values dropped by 70% and 80% before the word ZEC even came into our dialogue. So we just -- we don't think the Mopar is an approach that is going to workable, it applies in the phase of what the states are looking to do. I don't think it will be that effective. We talked about MISO Zone 4. It's notable that. And we did Clinton in a way where would that have cleared in that auction or has that be excluded by the Mopar, the price in MISO would have risen from $1.50 to $5 a megawatt [indiscernible]. That's certainly not going to address the downstate issues that ING and others are facing. At the end of it, we agree with what Chairman [indiscernible] , and she basically questioned the wisdom, approaching this problem set with more movers per unit that are receiving state environmental or attribute payments. And I think that's why New York guy saw them, MISO and others and [indiscernible] are not going in that direction. So that's -- we don't agree with the direction on the Moper, but when let me talk to you about something important that came up during the session and I think [indiscernible] and that is India talked about in Monday's session, and I'm going to loosely quote, I'm saying that we politely ignored energy market design problems that are undervaluing baseload assets. And we can't afford to ignore those problems anymore. And we completely agree with that. We have talked and talked over the last few years about energy pricing problems in the markets on that whole negative pricing, the fact that certain units gained set price during the hours, the over commitment of resources driving uplift and a whole host of issues that we've had technical conferences on and white papers on and we just having gotten -- started on working on that. And as a consequence, and not addressing those energy market issues, states and our customers are being deprived of assets that add resiliency, they add fuel diversity, and they add some environmental benefits. And so what we expect to do at the end of the second conference you heard California and others echo this is, we want to set a deadline for bringing the conclusion the energy market the form that we talked about. And we think that talking about Mopers or other things that interfere with state's rights before we fix the energy market problems, it's a little bit like putting your shoes on before you put your pants up. At the end of the day, it makes you a little bit silly. And so once we hit a reconstituted format at FERC, we're going to go after these energy price reforms. And we think Secretary Perry's memo opens the door to address these issues. So we think the last couple of days Secretary Perry's memo gives us an opening to look at some unfinished business that we had to get active. So long answer, big subject, but we see a lot of promise and what we saw over the last couple of days when we see a lot of promise and what DOE is looking at. We have to get the stuff over the finish line.

componenttext: So Julian, with the JV structure we have the opportunity to sell down further assets. The two that come to mind are AVS, our solar facility, which in 20 in -- that would not occur until 2019. We've got to get through the ITC recovery period for that. And then the second assets will be our Albany Green Energy facility, it's a wood-burning plant that has some contracts with 2 off takers down in Georgia. That's coming online this year, which could facilitate a drop-down end of '17, more likely '18. And that's all contemplated as part of the overall structure with the JV. With respect to the EBITDA I'm not going to drill down into that. And with respect to the EGTP given the sales process that we're working with the lenders on, I just don't think it's prudent for us to disclose. And then with respect to Mystic [indiscernible].

componenttext: We're not going to talk a lot of details. But as we see an asset in that portfolio as a potential to create value and recycle capital, we'll look at them. We will get it on an annual basis. We have some work to do on that one site, but we'll continue to evaluate it going forward.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017
componenttextpreview: We're still committed to clean portfolio. Being in the renewable business is still part of our strategy. At this point, maintaining the operational control, the maintenance of the facilities is important for us for our investment. We're getting a fair ret
componenttext: We're still committed to clean portfolio. Being in the renewable business is still part of our strategy. At this point, maintaining the operational control, the maintenance of the facilities is important for us for our investment. We're getting a fair return from those, but at this point, we felt that the valuation that we were getting in the market allowed us to recycle the capital. So we're not exiting the renewable business, and we continue to put about $125 million a year into solar at the C&I level for some of our national customers, and we'll continue to look at that portfolio how to best manage those investments going forward.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow up on Steve's question on the Department of Energy review. In terms of potential agencies or entities involved, would -- in your mind, is that most likely to be FERC or federal registration? In other words, I guess, I'm struggling to fi
componenttext: I wanted to follow up on Steve's question on the Department of Energy review. In terms of potential agencies or entities involved, would -- in your mind, is that most likely to be FERC or federal registration? In other words, I guess, I'm struggling to figure out how the Department of Energy itself could provide economic support for base load, whether that be nuclear, coal or gas. What sort of entities would most likely be involved? And I guess, I'm thinking if the states are providing value for environmental benefits from ZEC and the ISOs are providing the reliability benefit through capacity performance, what other elements are not being captured or what other tools are potential here?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is Joe Dominguez, again. Let me kind of -- give you a couple parts of that. First, we think the DOE has an important role in setting policy. I think the implementation requirement of that policy in certain instances be new legislation, it could be th
componenttext: This is Joe Dominguez, again. Let me kind of -- give you a couple parts of that. First, we think the DOE has an important role in setting policy. I think the implementation requirement of that policy in certain instances be new legislation, it could be things that are done at the NRC in terms of regulatory burdens on nuclear, but it would involve the commission in that sense. It could involve different changes and roles at FERC. But DOE is going to have an important voice in our view in this policy discussion, and we'll set the tone even if we can't complete all of the objectives. There are certain tools that DOE has. Section 202 has the authority under the Federal Power Act as an example allows them to secure resources in the market that are needed. That is a power that has been used sparingly I think only 2x in history, but certainly, there's a discussion around the use of it for base load resources. With regard to attributes payment, I think environmental attribute payment second think we're kind of wait and see by the administration goes on carbon. But I think your general sentiment is correct that, that's not something we see immediately coming out of the department. But you asked kind of more fundamental question as the states are covering environmental and PJM is covering reliability, what's left. Well, I'll tell you what's left. What's left is resiliency, there's a little bit of a different concept then reliability, reliability assumes that pipeline infrastructure and other critical pieces are in place, PJM assumes that and says whether there's some reliability impacts or reliability expectations could be met. Resiliency looks a little bit deeper at that and understands the impact of pipeline disruptions on natural gas fired generation and should we start modeling those sorts of things, is there a value there. The other piece that is not correctly valued in the market is fuel diversity. As we transition to a market that is made up more and more of just natural gas, we're exposing our customers to fuel price volatility in the long run. Those things because of the short-term nature of the markets are fully considered. But if you look at Secretary Perry's memo, I think it's a second bullet point -- second and third bullet points of that memo address those very issues.

componenttext: Yes. So we updated our dividend policy. The board updated the dividend policy about a year ago and gave you the clarity through 2018 on an annual 2.5% increase of the dividend. And so 2017 is going to be a big year to continue to have that focus. And so as we come through into 2018, we can have a dialogue with the board looking at -- we're achieving or close to achieving the goal towards '18, '19 on where we were going financially and our focus and strategy. So next year -- this year is a big year to perform, next year is a year where we should be working very hard to give you a longer-term view.

componenttext: Good morning. It's Joe Nigro. I'll answer kind of the last question first. Our retail margins for C&I origination still remain between that $2 to $4 we've talked about, well within that payment. As you know, the market hasn't seen volatility, and we continue to monitor that. The consolidation overall helps because there's less participants in the marketplace. As you know, we've acquired companies ourselves, obviously, other big entities have come to this space that haven't been there historically. That's been positive. We have seen some aggressive bidding behavior by some smaller entities in certain sectors like government contracting and other things. But overall, we continue to monitor this very closely and comfortable with the projections we have and our margins remain in that $2 to $4 space.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017

componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Josephine, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Exelon Corporation 2017 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Dan Eggers, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Josephine. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our first quarter 2017 earnings conference call. Leading the call today are Chris Crane, Exelon's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jack Thayer, Exelon's Chief Financial Of
componenttext:
Thank you, Josephine. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our first quarter 2017 earnings conference call. 
Leading the call today are Chris Crane, Exelon's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jack Thayer, Exelon's Chief Financial Officer. 
They're joined by other members of Exelon's senior management team, who will be available to answer your questions following our prepared remarks. 
We issued our earnings release this morning, along with the presentation, both of which can be found in the Investor Relations section of Exelon's website. 
The earnings release and other matters, which we discuss during today's call, contain forward-looking statements and estimates that are subject to various risks and uncertainties. Actual results could differ from our forward-looking statements based on factors and assumptions discussed in today's material and comments made during this call. Please refer to today's 8-K and Exelon's other SEC filings for discussions of risk factors and factors that may cause results to differ from management's projections, forecasts and expectations. 
Today's presentation also includes references to adjusted operating earnings and other non-GAAP measures. Please refer to the information contained in the appendix of our presentation and our earnings release for reconciliations between the non-GAAP measures and the nearest equivalent GAAP measures. We've scheduled 45 minutes for today's call. 
I'll now turn the call over to Chris Crane, Exelon's CEO.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan, and good morning, and thank you all for joining us. We're off to a great start in 2017. In March, we marked our 1 year anniversary of the merger between Exelon and Pepco Holdings. Since the close, PHI has successfully executed on merger c
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan, and good morning, and thank you all for joining us. 
We're off to a great start in 2017. In March, we marked our 1 year anniversary of the merger between Exelon and Pepco Holdings. 
Since the close, PHI has successfully executed on merger commitments, achieved synergy savings and made significant progress toward full integration. 
We also continue to work hard on the regulatory front. Since the beginning of the year, PHI closed out the Delmarva Maryland rate case and reached a settlement for our electric and gas rate case in Delaware. We are now down to just Pepco D.C. cases from our first planned cycle of rate case filings. 
That said, our regulatory team has already started the second cycle of rate cases at Pepco Maryland and ACE's planned. 
At ExGen, we completed the acquisition of FitzPatrick power plant, representing the 25th nuclear reactor where we have ownership stake. We welcome the new employees to the Exelon family. 
We also announced the Exelon Generation Renewables joint venture, which is allowing us to recycle capital at a valuation meaningfully above the value implied for our ExGen at our current share price. The JV allows us to make even faster progress on our debt reduction goals without diminishing our commitment to renewables -- renewable power.
We continue to focus on the legal challenges to the zero emission credits, or ZEC, in New York and Illinois. We remain confident that our arguments will prevail. We'll cover these points in more detail in the call, but I wanted to highlight what we have done while staying focused on the day-to-day operations. 
As shown on Slide 5, on a GAAP basis, we've earned $1.07 versus $0.19 a share last year. And on an operating basis, we earned $0.65 versus $0.68 last year, which puts us at the top of our $0.55 to $0.65 range and above consensus of $0.62. 
Moving to Slide 6. Our first operation -- our first quarter operational report was strong. Our color block charts highlight operating performance and customer satisfaction for the utilities. 
Legacy Exelon Utilities remain almost entirely first quartile. PECO actually had its best customer satisfaction rating ever during the first quarter. BGE experienced the best ever CAIDI and SAIFI performance of all time. At PHI, we're encouraged by the progress we are making and our customers are seeing the benefits. 
For example, by using a common lockout/tag-out process, a procedure that established as a zone of protection while restoring equipment, we were able to send over 400 employees and contractors from BGE, ComEd and PECO to support the storm restoration at Delmarva during Winter Storm Stella. 
As a result, Delmarva customers had their power restored 2 days sooner. Our thanks to everybody that helped in accomplishing that speedy recovery. 
The power of Exelon Utilities platform is a significant benefit to our customers. We continue to improve upon these metrics to meet reliability commitments we have made to provide better service to our customers. 
The nuclear team had a great quarter also. They completed 3 refueling outages and achieved a capacity factor of 94%. 
They also had the fastest refueling outage ever for Calvert Cliffs nuclear station 2, running 20 days. 
In the Power business, we realized renewable energy capture rate of nearly 96% and a power dispatch match of 94% -- over 99%. 
Our 2 newbuild CCGTs in Texas have both achieved first flyer and are now selling test power onto the grid. The state-of-the-art plants, which are totally nearly 2,200 megawatts, are on budget, on schedule for full commercial operations in the second quarter. We expect that they will be ready to participate in Texas this summer. 
At Constellation, our highly hedged portfolio in 2017 mitigates the impacts of weaker power prices and lower load given the mild winter weather. 
Even in this recent low volatility environment, our C&I business has been able to hold onto margins and keep customer renewables. 
On Slide 7, we view 2016 as a great success in delivering on our commitments and preserving some of our at-risk nuclear units by securing compensation for their clean energy attributes. 
For 2017, we're focused on executing on these gains we made last year, and more importantly, affirming the ZEC programs in the quarter. 
In New York, litigation is further along at this point. On March 29, the judge in New York Federal Court heard oral arguments on our motions to dismiss. We made strong arguments at this hearing and believe the law is clearly on our side. 
We do ask that -- we do get asked when we expect a decision, but the judge is not giving a specific time line or deadline to issue for order. If we prevail in a motion to dismiss, we would expect the other side to appeal that decision. If the judge denies our motion to dismiss, we'll move forward with the case as planned. 
As I've said previously, we're confident in the strength of our case. 
In Illinois, 2 groups of plaintiffs have challenged the ZEC and federal court and the cases are being before 1 judge. The plaintiffs filed for preliminary injunction on March 31. We intervened in that case on April 10, and we filed motions to dismiss. The judge has held a preliminary injunction motion while he receives full briefing on the motion to dismiss. He will then determine whether there is a legal basis to go forward. That briefing will be completed by May 15 and the judge is scheduled to inform the parties of his intention on May 22. 
In the interim, we start recognizing ZEC revenues in New York on April 1. In Illinois, the utilities have filed tariffs to begin collecting the ZEC payments on June 1. We don't expect the actual ZEC procurement process in Illinois to conclude until later in the fall. We remain confident that the ZEC programs will be upheld in the courts to the benefits of the state, the communities and these valuable resources. 
As we have discussed last year in our carbon policy principles, we see state programs as an essential mechanism until we have more cohesive federal policy that values clean baseload generation. Energy Secretary Perry's recent directive to look at the importance of preserving baseload generation is early but encouraging. We appreciate the secretary's focus to promote and needed market reforms to compensate these assets. We will support the DOE's effort as they move forward. 
Turning to the upcoming PJM auction. We understand the investment community is paying close attention particularly after the disappointing MISO capacity auction results. Joe Nigro is available to answer more detailed questions if you have them. But let me share a few thoughts around the auction. 
To the positive, we're going to 100% CP for the first time, which will put a higher performance burden on the entire fleet. We still think this should lead to a more responsible bidding, given the higher risk around nonperformance. The CETL numbers or the import capacity into ComEd and EMAAC LDAs have tightened this year versus last year. 
The tightening could flag more constrained market conditions than last year in these zones, which could help in separation. So the negative PJM load is demand forecast, again, for this auction and FERC-approved seasonal aggregation that will allow products that otherwise would not clear to participate in a 100% CP world. 
Finally, we have the risk of more uneconomic generation being built primarily in Pennsylvania and Ohio. 
These drivers are important, but we still expect clearing prices to come down to bidding behavior. 
You have seen us bid our assets in recent auctions to reflect the underlying economic needs of the individual plants, which in turn has led to some of our plants not clearing. You should expect us to bid our assets in the same responsible fashion in this next upcoming auction. 
Now let me the turn the call over to Jack to walk through the numbers.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and good morning, everyone. My remarks today will cover our first quarter results, an overview of our current rate cases, an update of our gross margin disclosures and a review of some of the events that occurred this quarter. Turning
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and good morning, everyone. My remarks today will cover our first quarter results, an overview of our current rate cases, an update of our gross margin disclosures and a review of some of the events that occurred this quarter. 
Turning to Slide 8. We had a strong quarter financially and operationally across the company. For the first quarter, we delivered adjusted non-GAAP operating earnings of $0.65 per share at the top of our guidance range of $0.55 to $0.65 per share. This compares to $0.68 per share for the first quarter of 2016. 
Exelon's utilities delivered a combined $0.47 per share. Versus our plan, the utility results were impacted by unfavorable weather at PECO and PHI, which was more than offset by O&M timing across all the utilities. With 70% of our distribution rate base and decoupled jurisdictions, including ComEd starting in 2017, we experienced less volatility on our utility earnings from record warm weather in January and February than if we did not have these programs. To help put this winter in context, this was the first time in 146 years when there was no snow on the ground in Chicago for both January and February. 
Looking across PJM, January and February were the warmest on record since data started being collected in 1950. 
Generation had a strong quarter relative to plan, earning $0.18 per share. We had good performance from our nuclear assets with better capacity factors than budgeted and our Constellation team, once again, delivered strong results despite weak power prices and low volatility. 
Turning to Slide 9. The $0.65 per share in the first quarter this year was $0.03 per share lower than the first quarter of 2016. To the positive, we had a full quarter of contribution from PHI relative to only 8 days last year, which added $0.09. The other utilities benefited from rate relief and higher rate base, partly offset at PECO with even milder weather than last year. 
ExGen was down year-over-year primarily on the known impacts of lower capacity prices and power price realization as well as more plant refueling outages. 
Turning to Slide 10. We are reaffirming our full year guidance range of $2.50 to $2.80 per share. We expect to deliver operating earnings of $0.45 to $0.55 in the second quarter compared with $0.65 last year. Our second quarter results will include contributions from the FitzPatrick plant and the impacts of the New York ZEC program that started on April 1. The Illinois ZEC legislation will go into effect on June 1 and plant procurement is expected to occur later this fall. Plants receiving contracts would recognized revenues retroactive to the June 1 effective date. 
Moving to Slide 11. Our utilities continue to execute well, delivering strong earned returns in the quarter. Looking at the trailing 12-month booked ROEs, we saw nice improvements even relative to what we showed last quarter. 
At PHI, we saw all of the utilities restore gains with some help coming as revenues from the first cycle of rate cases are starting to flow through to results. 
For the legacy Exelon Utilities, we continue to see strong earned ROEs, over 10%, that lift the consolidated Exelon utilities platform to nearly 10%, including PHI. 
We have plenty of work to do at utilities and with our regulators to keep improving the product we're delivering to our customers. But we're happy with where the overall business is performing. We're, obviously, pleased with where our earned ROEs are trending, but I want to remind you that there will be variability in the earned ROEs that are different utilities as we go forward. The timing of rate case implementation, weather comparability and in-service dates will all impact results. 
We think the ability to earn strong ROEs and the plan that we have in place at PHI to improve their ROEs will be the recipe for our future success. 
On Slide 12, we have an update on our rate cases. Since our fourth quarter call, we have closed out the Delmarva Maryland case with a revenue increase of $38 million. We've also reached unanimous settlements in our Delmarva Delaware electric and gas cases for $31.5 million and $4.9 million, respectively and would expect commission approval during the second quarter. 
From our first cycle of planned rate cases, we're now down just to the Pepco D.C. case, where we expect a Commission decision later in July. We're proud of the hard work from our utilities and regulatory teams. These efforts are helping to get PHI's revenues and our book ROEs back on course while we simultaneously improve performance for our customers. 
As we've shared with you many times before, we've always viewed the turnaround in PHI earned ROEs as a 2 rate case cycle process. To that end, we filed our second rate cases at ACE and Pepco Maryland this quarter. 
Combined with the outstanding cases from the first cycle that I previously mentioned, we are currently asking for $252 million in revenues, which reflect recovery on multiple years of capital investments that have been made to improve the reliability of the grid across these jurisdictions. We expect the final ruling on Pepco Maryland and ACE likely in Q4 2017 and first quarter of 2018, respectively. We plan to file a second cycle of cases in most, if not all, of PHI's jurisdictions in 2017 with all completed by the end of 2018, putting us in a position to earn between 9% and 10% ROEs in 2019. More details on the rate case is in our schedules to be found on Slides 29 through 36 in the appendix. 
Slide 13 provides our gross margin update for ExGen. In 2017, total gross margin is flat to our last disclosure. 
During the quarter, we executed on $150 million of power new business and $50 million of non-power new business. We're highly hedged for the rest of this year and are well balanced on our generational load matching strategy. 
Total gross margin decreased in the first quarter by $50 million in both 2018 and 2019 due to the impact of price changes on our open portfolio. We ended the quarter approximately 12% to 15% behind our ratable hedging program in 2018 and 8% to 11% behind ratable in 2019 when considering cross-commodity hedges. The majority of our length is concentrated in the Midwest to align to our fundamental view of spot market upside at NiHub. Although we have increased our length in other regions as well. 
We're comfortable with being more open when we look at market fundamentals. For example, forward regional natural gas prices today are over $1 per MMBtu higher than they realized last year, yet the forwards for power are only about $1 per megawatt higher. We do not believe that is a sustainable situation. 
To that point, I should note the power prices have risen since the start of the second quarter and have reversed about half of the first quarter price declines. 
On Slide 14, we have highlighted some key recent events. On March 31, 2017, we executed on the creation of the Exelon Generation Renewables JV, which will provide us with $400 million of pretax cash, including allocated debt that puts total JV enterprise value at approximately $1.7 billion. The price implies an EV to EBITDA multiple over 10x and a dollar per kW value over $1,200. 
The JV consists of 1,296 megawatts of renewable generation capacity, which is about 35% of our renewables output and has an average contract life of 14 years. The JV structure provides the option to drop down contractor renewable assets from our portfolio in the future. The proceeds from this sale will be used to accelerate our deleveraging strategy. 
Also on March 31, we closed on the acquisition of the FitzPatrick nuclear station from Entergy, which adds 838 megawatts of nuclear capacity to our portfolio. 
As you know, the FitzPatrick plant is part of the New York ZEC program, and we'll receive ZEC payments for the next 12 years, which started on April 1. The plant is now operated by Exelon, and I'm happy to report we had a clean cutover of FitzPatrick on to the Exelon platform. We're excited to have the FitzPatrick employees as part of the Exelon family. 
Our Exelon Generation Texas partnership, commonly referred to as EGTP, is a portfolio of 3,476 megawatts of gas generation in Texas. In 2014, we raised $675 million of nonrecourse project finance for the assets, which currently has a balance of approximately $650 million. With the downturn in ERCOT power markets, these assets have been under pressure with the debt trading at a discounted face value for some time and the plants struggling to generate adequate cash flows. 
Due to the combination of challenged cash flows and our decision not to inject additional equity, we have come to terms with the lenders to pursue an orderly sale of the assets on their behalf. 
The modest current earnings and all the debt are still included in our financial outlook. However, we see the ultimate exit from these assets being accretive to our EPS and debt-to-EBITDA multiple starting in 2018. 
In light of the process, we're not in the position to expand further on this transaction. 
Finally, during the quarter, we decided to discontinue the sales process of the Mystic 8 and 9 assets. We were exploring the sale of these assets as a direct result of interest received from potential buyers. During the sales process, we ran into some issues with the fuel supply agreement that needs to be addressed, and as we've said, we would only transact if we realize a price greater than our [ mutual ] whole value. Our continuing to own this assets does not impact our commitments on our debt-to-EBITDA target and debt reduction plans that we've already shared with you. 
Turning to Slide 15. We remain committed to maintaining a strong balance sheet in our investment-grade credit rating. We're forecasting to be at 3.2x debt-to-EBITDA at ExGen by the end of 2017 and have a clear path to our long-term target of 3x debt-to-EBITDA. 
On a recourse debt basis, we're already well ahead of our target, and taking into account the sale of EGTP, we would be on target overall. As we said before, we will look to retire Holdco debt once we have reached 3x target at ExGen. 
I'll now turn the call back to Chris for his closing remarks.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. This brings us to -- back to our value proposition shown on Slide 16, which looks familiar. It is unchanged from our last earnings report, and we remain committed to these points. We continue to grow the utility rate base at 6.5% annually th
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. This brings us to -- back to our value proposition shown on Slide 16, which looks familiar. It is unchanged from our last earnings report, and we remain committed to these points. We continue to grow the utility rate base at 6.5% annually through 2020 and regulated EPS by 6% to 8% annually through 2020. We continue to use free cash flow generated at ExGen to fund incremental equity needs at the utilities of $2.5 billion and pay down approximately $3 billion of debt over the next 4 years at ExGen and the holding company. We are focused on optimizing value for ExGen business by seeking fair compensation for our carbon-free generation fleet, closing uneconomic plants, opportunistically selling assets where it makes sense to accelerate our debt reduction plan and maximizing value through our gen-to-load matching strategy. We continue to focus on sustaining strong investment-grade credit metrics and grow our dividend in a consistent, visible manner. 
Thank you for your interest, and we're now ready for questions.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. Second question, and maybe it's not something you're able to really engage with me on the call on, but one of the reasons why I think the stock is underperformed is because people are looking, obviously, you've had a little bit of softness in the '1
componenttext: Okay. Second question, and maybe it's not something you're able to really engage with me on the call on, but one of the reasons why I think the stock is underperformed is because people are looking, obviously, you've had a little bit of softness in the '18, '19 curves. You already told us that's bounced a little bit, but people are looking forward to sort of 2020 roll coming this fall and looking at the open, theoretically, open position and worried about the capacity market print and thinking, well, 2020 is going to be another down year. So I don't know if you can comment on where -- how that looks today and also how that dovetails with what you continue to do with vis-a-vis debt reduction at ExGen. Because while the balance sheet looks like it's in absolutely great shape today, if EBITDA keeps going south, it's sort of a -- the bar keeps going up every year in terms of how -- what you have to do with your cash flow to keep it at that level of leverage.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017
componenttextpreview: A couple thoughts, Greg. One, I think it's probably, given the liquidity in the market, premature to forecast our 2020 ExGen earnings. But one thing to keep in context. On a recourse basis, by 2020, we'll have $4 billion of debt. That is the most pristine
componenttext: A couple thoughts, Greg. One, I think it's probably, given the liquidity in the market, premature to forecast our 2020 ExGen earnings. But one thing to keep in context. On a recourse basis, by 2020, we'll have $4 billion of debt. That is the most pristine balance sheet, I think, in the sector. So from a strength perspective with the balance sheet and ability to deal with the cyclicality of markets, I think we're well positioned. Our fundamental perspective would be that as liquidity returns to the market, prices are going up across and our hedging approach and the link that we're carrying relative to ratable is demonstrative of that. So I think it's meaningfully premature to be trading on 2020 in 2017.

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017
componenttextpreview: A question on -- you mentioned, I think, that you would be bidding the units in the PJM auction in the same, I think you said, responsible fashion. Can you give us any insight into what you see is different in the PJM auction set up with respect to, say,
componenttext: A question on -- you mentioned, I think, that you would be bidding the units in the PJM auction in the same, I think you said, responsible fashion. Can you give us any insight into what you see is different in the PJM auction set up with respect to, say, the Quad, which has the ZECs and Clinton which, obviously, clear they're at a low price in MISO. Is there any -- anything we should be thinking about as we sort of compare those 2 situations?

headline: Exelon Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 03, 2017
componenttextpreview: It's Joe Nigro. I'll take that question and answer. And as you know, I'll start by saying we have a long-standing practice of really not discussing our bidding strategy around capacity auctions and where we think it will clear. I think there is one thing
componenttext: It's Joe Nigro. I'll take that question and answer. And as you know, I'll start by saying we have a long-standing practice of really not discussing our bidding strategy around capacity auctions and where we think it will clear. I think there is one thing though you have to take into account, is the timing of the 2 auctions. The MISO auction was for June of this year through May of next year and the PJM auction, obviously, is much further out in the curve. When you think about the operation for the power plant and the fuel loaded in the core at Clinton, for example, that plant was going to continue to operate during that period. What I will say about Quad Cities in the bidding is we're going to continue to remain responsible in the way we bid our capacity, reflecting the underlying economics of our plant, and that's consistent with what we've done with past auctions. I think the major question mark with this auction continues to be, as Chris mentioned, bidding behavior from the existing generations as well as the discipline associated with newbuilds. As it relates to existing facilities, we continue to see economically challenged plants that have cleared previous auctions. And in addition to that, we see the economics of newbuilds being marginal. In the last auction, we cleared about 27 gigawatts of base capacity, which was about 16% of the total procurement. And it remains to be seen how that 27 gigawatts will participate in this auction. But the big variable, as I mentioned, will continue to be the bidding of all the plants, and we will remain disciplined in that regard with all our facilities.

componenttext: It's something that we follow closely, not only as a supplier, but for the industry. We have reviewed our positions that we have commercially with them. We're not concerned at this time, but we'll continue to watch it closely. Fuel fabrication, we continue to see that as an ongoing entity in the services business. We continue to gain support and see that is an ongoing entity. None of us know how it's going to shake out yet, but we have minimal exposure there.
